div.p: THE VIRTUOSO. A COMEDY, Acted at the Duke's Theatre. Written by THOMAS SHADWELL.
LONDON, Printed by T. N. for Henry Herringman, at the Anchor in the Lower Walk of the New Exchange, 1676.

div.head: To the Most Illustrious Prince WILLIAM, Duke of NEWCASTLE, &c.
div.p: SO long as your Grace pèrsists in Obliging, I must go on in Acknowledging; nor can I let any opportunity pass of telling the World how much I am favored by you; or any occasion slip of assuring your Grace, that all the actions of my life shall be dedicated to your service; who by your Noble Patronage, your Generosity and Kindness, and your continual Bounty, have made me wholly your Creature: nor can I forbear to declare, that I am more obliged to your Grace, than to all Mankind. And my misfortune is, I can make no other return, but a declaration of my grateful Resentments.

When I shew'd your Grace some part of this Comedy, at Welbeck, being all that I had then written of it, you were pleased to express your great liking of it, which was a sufficient encouragment for me to proceed in it: And when I had finish'd it, to lay it humbly at your feet; what ever I write, I will submit to your Grace, who are the greatest Master of Wit, the most exact Observer of Mankind, and the most accurate Judge of Humour, that ever I knew. And were I not assured of the Greatness of your favour, I should be afraid of the excellency of your judgment.

I have endeavoured in this Play at Humor, Wit, and Satyr, which are the three things (however I may have fallen short in my attempt) which your Grace has often told me, are the life of a Comedy. Four of the Humors are entirely new; and (without vanity) I may say. I ne'r produc'd a Comedy that had not some natural Humour in it not represented before, nor I hope ever shall. Nor do I count those Humours which a great many do, that is to say, such as consist in using one or two By-words; or in having a fantastick, extravagant Dress, as many pretended Humours have; nor in the affectation of some French words, which several Plays 〈◊〉 shown us. I say nothing of impossible, unnatural Farce Fools, which some intend for Comical who think it the easiest thing in the world to write a Comedy, and yet will sooner grow rich upon their ill Plays 〈◊〉 write a good one: Nor is downright silly folly a Humour, as some take it to be for 'tis a 〈◊〉 natural Imperfection; and they might as 〈◊〉 call it a humour of Blindness in a blind man, or Lameness in a lame one: Or as a celebrated French 〈◊〉 has the humour of one
who speaks very fast, and of another who speaks very slow: But Natural imperfections are not fit Subjects for Comedy, since they are not to be laugh'd at, but pitied. But the Artificial folly of those, who are not Coxcombs by Nature, but with great Art and Industry make themselves so, is a proper object of Comedy, as I have discoursed at large in the Preface to the Humorists, written five years since: Those slight circumstantial things mentioned before are not enough to make a good Comical Humour: which ought to be such an affectation, as misguides men in Knowledge, Art, or Science, or that causes defection in Manners, and Morality, or perverts their minds in the main Actions of their lives. And this kind of Humour I think I have not improperly described in the Epilogue to the Humorist.

But your Grace understands Humour too well not to know this, and much more than I can say of it. All I have now to do, is, humbly to Dedicate this Play to your Grace, which has succeeded beyond my expectation, and the Humours of which have been approved by Men of the best Sense and Learning. Nor do I hear of any profest Enemies to the Play, but some Women and some Men of Feminine understandings, who like slight Plays onely, that represent a little tattle sort of Conversation like their own; but true Humour is not liked or understood by them, and therefore even my attempt towards it is condemned by them. But the same people, to my great comfort, damn all Mr. Johnson's Plays, who was 〈◊〉 the best Drammatick Poet that ever was, or, I believe, ever will be; and I had rather be Author of one Scene in his best Comedies, than of any Play this Age has produced. That there are a great many faults in the conduct of this Play, I am not ignorant. But I (having no Pension but from the Theatre, which is either unwilling, or unable, to reward a Man sufficiently, for so much pains as correct Comedies require) cannot allot my whole time to the writing of Plays, but am forced to mind some other business of Advantage. (Had I as much Money, and as much time for it) I might perhaps write as Correct a Comedy as any of my Contemporaries. But I hope your Grace will accept of this with all its imperfections; which since the Royal Family have received favorably, I have all my aim, if it be approved by your Grace, who are next to them, in the greatest esteem and observance of,

closer.signed: My Lord Your Graces most obliged humble Servant, THOMAS SHADWEL.

lg.l: YOu come with such an eager appetite
To a late Play, which gave so great delight;
Our Poet fears, that by so rich a Treat,
Your Palates are become too delicate.
Yet since y'have had Rhime for a relishing Bit,
To give a better taste to Comick Wit.
But this requires expence of time and pains,
Too great, alas, for Poets slender gains.
For Wit, like China, should long buri'd lie,
Before it ripens to good Comedy;
A thing we ne'r have seen since Johnson's days,
And but a few of his were perfect Plays.
Now Drudges of the Stage must oft appear,
They must be bound to scribble twice a year.
Thus the thin thred-bare Vicar still must toil,
While the fat lazie Doctor bears the spoil.
In the last Comedy some Wits were shown;
In this are Fools that much infest the Town.
Plenty of Fops, grievances of the Age,
Whose nauseous Figures ne'r were on a Stage.
He cannot say they'll please you, but they're new;
And he hopes you will say, he has drawn▪ em true.
He's sure in Wit he cann't excel the rest,
He'd but be thought to write a Fool the best.
Such Fools as haunt and trouble Men of Wit,
And spight of them will for their Pictures sit.
Yet no one Coxcomb in this Play is shown;
No one Man's humour makes a part alone,
But scatter'd follies gather'd into one.
He says, if with new Fops he can but please;
He'll twice a year produce as new as these.

item.hi: Ribband-Weavers, Sick and Lame People, Porters, Servants, Masqueraders.

div.head: ACT I.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: THou great Lucretius! Thou profound Oracle of Wit and Sence! thou art no Trifling-Lándskip-Poet, no Fantastick Heroick Dreamer, with empty Descriptions of Impossibilities, and mighty sounding Nothings. Thou reconcil'st Philosophy with Verse, and dost, almost alone, demonstráte that Poetry and Good Sence may go together.

lg.l: Omnis enim per se Divûm Natura 〈◊〉 est,
Immortali aevo summà cum pace fruatur,
Semota à nostris Rebus, sejunctaque longè,
Nam privata dolore omni, privata perîclis,
Ipsa suis pollens opibus, nihil indiga nostri,
Nec bene promeritis capitur, nec tangitur ira.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Bruce, Good Morrow; what great Author are thou▪ chewing the Cud upon? I look'd to have found you with▪ your▪ Head-ake, and your Morning-Qualms.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We should not live always hot-headed; we should give our selves leave sometimes to think.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Lucretius! Divine Lucretius: But my Noble Epicurean▪ what an Unfashionable Fellow▪ art thou, that in this Age art given to understand Latine?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Longvil, I am a bold Fellow to pretend to it, when 'tis accounted Pedantry for a Gentleman to spell, and where the Race of Gentlemen is more degenerated than that of Horses.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p:
It must needs be so: for Gentlemen care not upon what strain they get their Son, nor how they 〈◊〉 'em, when they
have got 'em: the best of 'em now have a kind of Education like Pages; and you shall 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 a Young Fellow of this Age that does not look like one of those overgrown Animals newly manumitted from ●…unk-Breeches.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Some are first Instructed by Ignorant-young-housholdPedan●…s, who dare not whip the Dunces, their Pupils, for fear of their Lady-Mothers▪ then before they can Conster and Pearce, they are sent into France, with sordid illiterate Creatures, call'd Dry'd-Nurses, or Governors; Engines of as little use as Pacing-Saddies, and as unfit to Govern 'em as the Post-Horses they ride to Paris on: From whence they return with a little smattering of that Mighty, Universal Language, without being ever able to write true English.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: O but then they'l value 'em for speaking good French.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Perhaps good French may be spoken with little sence; but good English cannot.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Thou art in the right: but then there are a sort of hopeful Youths that do not travel; and they are either such as keep Company with their Sisters, and visit their Kindred, and are a great comfort to their Mothers, and a scorn to all others; or they are sparks that early break loose from Discipline, and at Sixteen for sooth set up for Men of the Town.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Such as come Drunk and Screaming into a Play-House, and stand upon the Benches, and toss their full Periwigs and empty Heads, and with their shrill unbroken Pipes, cry, Dam-me, this is a Damn'd Play; Prethee let's to a Whore, Jack. Then says another with great Gallantry, pulling out his Box of Pills, Damme. Tom, I am not in a condition; here's my Turpentine for my Third Clap: when you would think he was not old enough to be able to get one.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Heav'n be prais'd, these Youths, like untimely Fruit, are like to be rotten before they are ripe!

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: These are sure the only Animals that live without thinking: A Sensible Plant has more imagination than most of 'em.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Gad, if they go on as they begin, the Gentlemen of the next Age will scarce have Learning enough to claim the benefit of the Clergy for Man-slaughter.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p:
The highest pitch our Youth do generally arrive at▪ is to have a form, a fashion of Wit, a Rotine of speaking, which they get by imitation; and generally they imitate the extravagancies
of witty Men drunk, which they very discreetly practice sober; but in so clumsie and awkard a way, that methinks it should make witty men out of love with their Vices; as Prentices wearing Pantaloons, would make Gentlemen lay by the Habit.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: These are sad Truths: but I am not such a fop to disquiet my self one minute for a thousand of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You have Reason, say what we can, the Beastly Restive World will go its way; and there is not so foolish a Creature as ●… Reformer.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Thank Heav'n, I am not such a publick-spirited fop, to lose one moment of my private pleasure for all that can happen without me.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Thou art a Philosopher: and now thou talk'st of private pleasure, what think'st thou of our Adventure with Clarinda and Miranda, the Vertuoso's, Sir Nicholas Gimcrak's Neeces? See the danger of going to Church, Longvil: I advised thee against it; 'twas a fine Curiosity, and has cost us dear.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Did ever I think we two should be caught any way in a Church?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Tis a little strange that we, that have run together into all the Vices of Men, of Wit and Gentlemen, should at last together fall into the Vice of Fools and Country-Squires, Love.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We that have wonder'd at all other amorous Coxcombs must now laugh at one another. I am amaz'd at thy passion for Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Brute.
sp.p: And I no less at thine for Miranda. There's Witchcraft in't, to love where there's such apparent difficulty: for Virtuoso is as jealous as an Italian Uncle; his jealousie, helpt by the vigilancy and malice of that impertinent Strumpet his Wife, keeps 'em from all manner of address. Letters they have received from us, and we can have no answer; what the Devil's left for us to do in this case?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Fall down and worship me! I have found out the Noblest Tool to work with, and the most excellent Coxcomb that Nature e'er began, or Art e're finish'd.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Thou reviv'st my dying hope. Who is't?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A Rascal that is Vertuoso's Admirer, Flatterer, and great Confident, the only Man he'll trust his Neeces with, who has discover'd to me that he has a passion for your Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Curse on him: But a Rival's a very improper Instrument.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But this is a Rival so conceited of his own parts, that he can never be jealous of anothers. He is indeed a very choise Spirit; the greatest Master of Tropes and Figures: The most Ciceronian Coxcomb: the noblest Orator breathing; he never speaks without Flowers of Rhetorick; In short, he is very much abounding in words, and very much defective in sense, Sir Formal Trifle.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: He's an Original indeed, the most Florid Knight alive; I have some little knowledge of him.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have perswaded him, that you and I are the greatest Philosophers, and the greatest Admirers of the Virtuoso and his Works that can be: This has already produc'd that good effect, that Sir Formal has this morning been with me from his noble Friend Sir Nicholas, to invite me to come to his House to see a Cock-Lobster dissected, and afterwards to Dine with him; and will be here with the same Message to you.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: How I applaud thy Wit! but why wouldst not thou communicate thy design before-hand?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I was resolv'd to surprise thee with it if it took, and to conceal it if it did not,

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir Samuel Hearty has sent you word, he will come and give you a visit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: There's an Ass, an Original of another kind; one that thinks that all Mirth consists in noise, tumult, and violent laughter: At once, the merriest and the dullest Rogue alive— One that affects a great many nonsensical by-words, which he takes to be Wit, and uses upon all occasions.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But the best part of his Character is behind; he is the most amorous Coxcomb, the most designing and adventurous Knight alive; a great Masquerader, and has forty several disguises to make love in; and has been the most unlucky Fellow breathing, in that and all other adventures. He has never made Love where he was not refus'd, nor wag'd War where he was not beaten. Here he is.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
Tom. Bruce. Good morrow to thee. Dear Jack Longvil, how dost do? 'Faith I wish'd you with me last night; we were a knot of merry Rogues of thirteen or fourteen of us got
together, sung, and tore, and roar'd, and ranted 'igad all weathers, and drunk and laugh'd Dagger out o'sheath, I vow to gad: We were upon the high Ropes, i'faith. Hey poop— troll— come aloft Boys— ha-ha-ha. Ah Rogues, that you had been with us, 'ifaith. Ha-ha-ha.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 and wou'd we had.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Igad Boys: we'd have paid you off. We swing'd it away 'ifaith: We were so merry, o'my Conscience, you might have heard us half a mile.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What a Divine hearing was that?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Faith I was pure company, I was never on a better pin in my life. There was one of the Company wou'd needs pretend to be a Wit forsooth; but 'ifaith Boys I run him down so, the Devil take me, he had not a word to throw at a Dog about business. When ever he was impertinent, I took him up with my old repartée; Peace, said I, Tace is Latine for a Candle; and when e'er he began again, Tace is Latine for a Candle again said I. Thus I run him down with a Hey poop! Whoo! ha-ha-ha! he had not a word, not one word, I vow to gad. Ha-ha-ha!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: As this Fellow thinks all mirth consists in noise, so he thinks all Wit is in running a Man down, as he calls it; not considering that impudence does that better.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Faith I was very frolick; and there came a fellow abruptly into our company. I whip'd him up to. Hey! slap, dash! gave him a kick in the arse to drink, and made Pilgarlike go ten times faster down stairs than he came up, i'faith, Boys

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: But this may cost you a Challenge, Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Challenge! igad if he does challenge me, I'll run him through the Lungs about that bus'ness. He shall not only blow out a Candle with his wound, but the Sun shall shine through him. Pox! he's a raw fellow, he does not know what 'tis to have a Towel drawn through his Body.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This Fellow's brains, like some bottle-beer, fly all intofroth.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: So brisk and dull a Rogue I never saw.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Come, 'faith we are choice Lads, and should make much of one another. I have indeed to night an Intrigo with a Lady, and I am to venture in a disguise. I give a Masquerade you know, and, I hope will be there. But to morrow night, 'faith I'll be very drunk about business. Ha Boys! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir, one Sir Formal Trifle bids me tell you, he's come to pay his Devoir to you; he charged me to use that expression, I know not what he means by it.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Twas very quaintly exprest: desire him to come up.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Oh I have often seen him at Sir Nicholas Gimcrack's house, the Virtuoso; 'faith of a grave fellow, he's a very ingenious Rogue, and i'gad he has a fine way with him—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I never knew any man that had a way with him (as they call it) that was not a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: He has a notable Vein of Oratory, a brave Delivery; and when he's in the humor, i'gad he'll speak finely, finely very finely.—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I humbly kiss all your hands in general, but, Sir, yours in a more particular manner.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir Formal, your most humble Servant; you do me a great deal of honour in this visit.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sir, I never could admit a thought within the slender Sphere of my imagination, that could once suggest to me the not meeting with a good reception, from a person that is so strictly oblig'd by, and so nicely practis'd in the severer rules and stricter methods of honour, as you are.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir, you oblige me with your fair Character.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my sincerity, I wholly eschew all Oratory, and Compliments, with persons of your worth and generosity. And though I must confess upon due occasions, I am extremely delighted with those pretty spruce expressions, wherewith Wit and Eloquence use to tric●… up humane thoughts, and with the gaudy dress that smoother Pens so finely cloth them in, yet I never us'd the least tincture of Rhetorick with my Friend, which I hope you'll do me the Honor to let me call you— I think I am florid—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I told you i'faith he'd speak notably; he has a Silver Tongue.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Oyes! a Golden one! What would such Coxcombs do, if there were not greater to admire them? This Sir Formal is call'd a well-spoken man, with a pox to him—▪

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir, I shall think my self honored with the Title of your Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: It is so much to my advantage, that I do assure you, Sir Formal Trifle shall never give Mr Bruce any occasion to believe, that he shall omit any opportunity of avowing himself to all the World, to be the most humble and obedient of his Servants. Sweet Mr. Longvil, having already this morning paid my devoir to you, I shall at present onely tell you that, which I hope is no news to you; to wit, that I am your most humble Servant. There I think I was concise and florid.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You do me too much honor.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Is 〈◊〉 so great a Rascal upon earth as an Orator, that wou'd slur and top upon our understandings, and impose his false conceits for true reasoning, and his florid words for good sense?

sp.speaker: Longv!
sp.p: Your ●…ully, with his false Dice and Box, is an honester man.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I am afflicted at the late falling out between Sir Nicholas and your noble self, which has deprived me of so frequently enjoying the honor of kissing your fair hands there.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, your Servant, your Servant: 'faith I am very sorry for't too. But I shall be glad to wait upon you, and drink his health in a glass of Burgundy, and be very merry about business: He's a fine person 'ifaith, though he does not care much for Wit▪

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: And now Mr Bruce after these little digressions which my particular esteem of every person in this presence has engaged me to, I am to inform you, that my noble Friend Sir Nicholas Gimcrack does by me invite you, with your Friend, being Philosophers, and consequently his Admirers, to come to his house this fore-noon, to see the dissection of a little Animals, commonly called a Chichester Cock-Lobster; and afterwards to take a dish of meat, and discourse of the noble Operation, and to sport an Author over a Glass of Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam
sp.p: Ha! this will prove for my design.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Give me your Orator for dispatch. What a flourish the Rogue has made to invite us to dinner.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir, I will not do my self the injure to fail two fuch Ingenious and Learned men as Sir Nicholas and your self▪

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉.
sp.p:
Alass, Sir, 〈◊〉 I am but his shadow, his humble Admirer; but I will undertake for him▪ Fame has not promis'd
more of him to your expectation, than he will perform to your understanding. Trust me, he is the finest speculative Gentleman in the whole World, and in his Cogitations the most serene Animal alive: Not a Creature so little, but affords him great Curiosities: He is the most admirable person in the Meletetiques, viz. in Reflections and Meditations, in the whole World. Not a Creature so inanimate, to which he does not give a Tongue; he makes the whole World Vocal; he makes Flowers, nay, Weeds, speak eloquently, and, by a noble kind of Prosopopeia, instruct Mankind.

And, Sir, though I ignore not what the envy of Detractors have express'd of him, yet, in short, I opine him to be the most curious and inquisitive Philosopher breathing; and I will let him know you intend to wait on him; within two hours he will show. 'Tis his time of Operation.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We will not fail. What an Employment has this Fool under him? he is the Chorus to his Puppet-show.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I would rather be Trumpeter to a Monster, and call in the Rabble to see a Calf with six legs, than shew such a Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Pray, Sir, commend me heartily to Sir Nicholas, and tell him, Faith and Troth I am sorry my Wit should offend him; and I shall henceforth endeavor to be as dull as I can to merit his esteem. I confess I was a little too aiery and brisk about that bus▪ ness: but 'faith I am his most humble Servant, and have a Sword and Arm at his service, and 'gad will draw it against any man breathing, in defence of his Person and Philosophy; and so let him know from Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I shall perform your commands, and doubt not but to do you service in it. Gentlemen agen, I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Sir Samuel, how came your Wit to offend the Virtuoso?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Faith I was very well there; but you know I am an aiery brisk merry Fellow, and facetious: and his grave Philosophical humor, did not agree with mine. Besides, h does not value Wit at all, he wo'nt be pleas'd with you, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why, he did not like me at all; he's an enemy to Wit, as all Vertuoso's are.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sure if he had lik'd Wit, he would have lik'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: That I think without vanity, but you must know, I pretended to Miranda.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Pox on him, what says he?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: And not to boast, I found my love would have had a good reception; but her malicious Sister, Clarinda, discover'd my Intriguo, and Sir Nicholas forbad me his house upon that bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What exception had he against you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why faith he would not dispose of his Niece to a Wit, he said.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A Wit! 'faith he might as well have call'd thee a Dromedary.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Peace, I say; Tace is Latine for a Candle, Ha-ha-ha. You know I can run you down. In short, he said▪ I was a Wit, a flashy Wit. But if you have any kindness in the World for me, you might help me in this Intriguo.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Now you are invited, let me wait on you in a Livery for one of your Footmen. I have forty several Periwigs for these Intriguo's and bus'nesses: 'gad if you will whip▪ slap-dash— I'll bring this bus'ness about as round as a Hoop.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Prethee, Longvil▪ let him go, that we may make sport with him, and abuse the Rogue damnably.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what, bring him to my Mistriss!

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Canst thou be jealous of so silly a Rascal?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Tis ill trusting the fantastick appetites of Women; they are subject to the Green-sickness of the mind, as well as that of the body: One makes them love Fools and Block-heads, as the other does Dirt and Char-coal.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: She's a Woman of Wit; besides, let him wear your Livery, and by your prerogative you may kick your Rival all this day, if he should be sawcy, which he will certainly be.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: That consideration prevails with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What say you, Boys? is it not an admirable Intriguo?— Hah!—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Sir Samuel, there is some difficulty: but, to serve you, we can refuse nothing. You shall do me the honour to wear a Livery of mine; I have new ones come home this morning my man will give you one.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: If I do not my bus'ness, Jack▪ I am the Son of a Tinder-box.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Well! Pray Mr. Tinder-box, go about it quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Gad I'll do't instantly, in the twinkling of a Bed-staff. Ha-ha-ha.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: In the twinkling of what?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hey! pull away, Rogues; in the twinkling of a Bed-staff! a witty way I have of expressing my self. I'll away.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Was there ever so sensless a Fop? words are no more to him than breaking wind, they only give him vent; they serve not with him to express thoughts, for he does not think.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: A Wit! a flashy Wit! a flashy Wit! What a dull Villain is this Virtuoso; But prethee take all occasions to kick this flashy Wit much; he'll give thee enough.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Pox on him▪ he has read Seneca: he cares not for kicking; he never scap'd kicking in any disguise he ever put on.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Nor in any of his own habits neither. But I'll in and dress me.

div.stage: Enter Miranda and Clarinda in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: Were ever Women so confin'd in England by a foolish Uncle? worse than an Italian. But that I should be loath to speak ill of the dead, I should think my Father was not Compos mentis when he made his Will, to bequeath us to the government of a Virtuoso only, because his first Wife was our Aunt.

sp.speaker: Clarin.
sp.p: A Sot, that has spent 2000 l. in Microscopes, to find out the Nature of Eels in Vinegar, Mites in a Cheese, and the Blu●… of Plums, which he has subtilly found out to be living Creatures.

sp.speaker: Miran.
sp.p: One who has broken his brains about the nature of Magots▪ who has study'd these twenty years to 〈◊〉 out the several sorts of Spiders, and never cares for understanding Mankind.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Shal we never get free from his jealousie, and the malice of this impertinent Wife?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Though he be jealous of us, yet he's as tame a civil London Husband to his Wife, as she can wish— who certainly Cuckolds him abundantly.

sp.speaker: Clar▪
sp.p: She hates us in her heart, because she thinks we see too much. To be confin'd, and to such impertinence too, puts me beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: ▪ Twill make Dogs ●…urst to be ty'd up, and sure 'twill provoke free-born Women more?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We should have as good company in ●… Go a; for none but Quacks and Fools come hither; and one of the worst of 'em is my foolish florid Coxcombe, Sir Formal.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: He has banish'd my Coxcomb, Sir Samuel; a brisk airy Fool, that there is some diversion in. He had as many tricks as a well educated Spaniel, would fetch and carry, and come over a stick for the King: He had some tricks of a Man too, and may pass Muster among the young gay fellows of this Town; and could sing all the new Tunes and Songs at the Play-houses.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And we are troubled with an old Fellow here in the House, his Uncle Snarl, a great Declaimer against the Vices of the Age, a clownish blunt Satyrical Fellow; a hater of all young people, and new Fashions.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But he is such a froward testy old fellow, he should be Wormed like a mad Dog.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We try his patience sometimes; but I am pleas'd to hear him abuse the Virtuoso his Nephew, who bears all in hope of his Estate. Snarle is a Fellow spares no body, always speaks what he thinks, and does what he pleases. But yet▪ Miranda, there's a worse misfortune than all this, that we two should, in a Church, when we should ha'been thinking of something else, fall in love with two men of Wit and Pleasure, who are two much Men of the Town to think of Marriage, we being too little Women of the Town to think of any other Love.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: We have Fortunes good enough to lure them to Matrimony, if that were all; but the worst part of the story is, he whom I love is in love with you, and your Man makes addresses to me, as their Letters tell us: And even these Men we cannot see, but at Church, or at a Play-house, when we are guarded by our malicious watchful Aunt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
If we could but see these Men privately, there yet might be some hopes; we might each of us use our Lover scurvily, and him we love we might charm with kindness;
for they are men that have known the pomps and vanities of this wicked World, too much to love a face onely.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If we could bring this about, I would stand out at nothing that might procure our freedome; the mischief is, if we rebel, Virtuoso will allow us nothing out of our Fortunes till we come of age.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Then we must e'en live upon the credit of a Reversion, as some young fellows do that wish their Fathers hang'd: I warrant thee we'll find credit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And lose our Reputations: we have much ado to keep 'em as we are.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let what will come on't, I am resolved to break out: he shall sooner stop a Tide than my Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Oh if your Knight Errants and we agree upon the point, they'll soon deliver us distressed Damsels from our Enchanted Castle.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine morning: fetch me a Pipe of Tobacco and a Match into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Here's old Snarl, he has call'd for his Tobacco too: he smoaks all day like a Kitchen-chimney.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Prethee let's teaze him a little, 'tis the greatest pleasure we have. Morrow Uncle—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: How now you Baggages! what do you abroad thus early? you us'd to be stewing a bed till eleven a clock, like paltry lazy Cockatrices, that are good for nothing, by the Mass: You'll make excellent Wives, Cuckold your Husbands immoderately: You mind nothing but prinking your selves up. A wholesome good housewifely Countrey Wench is worth a thousand of you, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You have a course stomach, and to such a one a Surloin of Beef were better than a dish of Wheat ears.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: A man must have ●… lusty stomach that has a mind to any of▪ the Town-Ladies; they have so many tricks to disguise themselves, washing, painting, patching, and their damn'd ugly new-fashion'd dresses, that a Man knows not what to make on 'em, by the Mass: Besides, I have not heard, that their Reputations are famous all over the World.

sp.speaker: Clad.
sp.p:
You are an old fashion'd Fellow, Uncle▪ and think no
Dress handsome, but that which Ladies wore at the Coronation of the last King.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And think no Ladies honest, but your old formal Creatures, that were in fashion in the year 1640▪ and censure all Ladies that have freedom in their carriage.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Freedom with a pox! ay, 'tis freedom indeed: But the last Age was an Age of innocence, you young Sluts you; now a company of Jillflirts, flanting vain Cockatrices, take more pains to lose Reputation, than those did to preserve it. I am afraid the next Age will have very few that are lawfully begotten in't, by the Mass. Besides, the young Fellows are like all to be effeminate Coxcombs, and the young Women Strumpets, in sadness, all Strumpets by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You are a fine old Satyr indeed; 'twere well if you decri'd Vices for any other reason but that you are past them.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: You pert Baggages, you think you are very handsome now, I warrant you. What a devil's this pound of hair upon your paltry frowses for? what a Pox are those Patches for? what are your faces sore? I'd not kiss a Lady of this Age, by the Mass, I'd rather kiss my horse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Heav'n, for the general good of our Sex, keep you still in that mind.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Some Ladies with scabs and pimples on their faces invented patches, and those that have none must follow: Just as our young Fellows imitate the French; their Summer fashion of going open-breasted came to us at Michaelmas, and we wore it all Winter; and their Winter-fashion of buttoning close their strait-long-wasted Coats, that made them look like Monkies, came not to us till Anarch, and our Coxcombes wore it all Summer. Nay, I'll say that for your comfort, the young fashionable Fellows of the Town have as little Wit as you have.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You had a better opinion of our Sex sure in your youth, were you never in love?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O yes, with himself alway▪

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Never with any such as you, I thank Heaven, I was never such an Ass; I'd not be such a Puppy for the World, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.p: Pish: you are an old insignificant Fellow, Nuncle, such as you should be destroyed, like Drones that have lost their 〈◊〉 and afford no Honey.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Marry come up, you young Slut, are you so liquorish after the Honey of Man? in sadness this is fine.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You have no pleasure but drinking, and smoaking, and riding with your Gambadoes on your little pacing Tit, to take a Pipe, and drink a cup of Ale at Hamstead or Highgate.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Prethee, you prating Slut, do not trouble me with your impertinence. What pleasure can a Man have in this coxcombly, scandalous Age; in sadness, I am almost asham'd to live in't, by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Then die in it, as soon as you can, if you do not like it▪

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Methinks, though all pleasures have left you, you may go to see Plays.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I am not such a Coxcomb, I thank God: I have seen 'em at Black-Fryers; pox, they act like Poppets now in sadness, I, that have seen Joseph Taylor, and Lowen, and Swanstead: Oh a brave roaring Fellow! would make the house shake again. Besides, I can never endure to see Plays since Women came on the Stage, Boys are better by half.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But here are a great many new Plays.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: New ones! yes, either damn'd insipid dull Farces, confounded toothless Satyrs, or plaguy Rhiming Plays, with scurvy Hero's, worse than the Knight of the Sun, or Amadis de Gaul; by the Mass. Pish, why should I talk with such foolish Girls. Here, Sirra, give me my Pipe of Tobacco, with the Match. So—
Go now, and fetch me a lusty Tankerd of Ale, with Nutmeg and Sugar in't—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Prethee do thee fling away his Cane, and I'll break his Pipe, which will almost break his heart—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Agreed. Fie Nuncle, is this your breeding, to take nasty Tobacco, and stink much before Ladies?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A way with it.

div.stage: Clarinda Flings away his Cane, Miranda breaks his Pipe.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! you sawcy Jades, what's this? I'll thrum you; 'twas well you flung away my Cane, you young Sluts; in sadness I'd ha'made Bamboo fly about your Jackets else, by the Mass. Ha! 'tis not broken all to pieces.
sp.stage: [He is stooping for his Pipe, one flings away his Hat and Periwig, the other thrusts him down.
sp.p: 'Ounds! you young Jades, I'll maul you, you Strumpets, you damn'd Cockatrices: I'll disinherit my Nephew, if he does not turn you out of doors, you Crocadills.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That's it we'd have, we'l weary you both of your lives till you bring it about.

sp.speaker: Snail.
sp.p: You young Jades, you Strumpets.

div.stage: [●…it Snarl, looking for his Hat and Periwig.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Let's away, he▪ ll beat us.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Ladies, whither so gay, and in such hast? Is Sir Nicholas here?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No no, Clarinda, come away.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Let me first violently ravish a kiss from your fair hands; I had this morning, ere I went out, tender▪ d you my service of this day; had I not opin'd, I should too early have disturb'd your Beauty: but, Madam, you ignore not, that those venturous Blossoms, whose over-hasty obedience to the early Spring, does anticipate the proper Season, do often suffer from the injuries of severer weather, unless protected by the happy patronage of some more benign shelter.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Farewell, I am in hast—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Her departure savors somewhat of abruptness—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Strumpets, Jades!

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Snarl, had my eyes sooner encounter'd you, I had more early paid you the Tribute of my respect, which I opine to be so much your due, that though I ignore not that you are happy in having many Admirers, yet—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: 'Ounds, if I be not reveng'd on those Cockatrices.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Yet I say, none of 'em is endu'd with a more zealous heart to do you service, than your most humble Servant Sir▪ Formal Triste.

sp.speaker: Snarl
sp.p: Pox! What do you trouble me with your foolish Rhetorick?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
What is it so disorders the Operative Faculties of your noble Soul? But I beseech you argue you me not of Oratory; though I confess it to be a great virtue to be florid: nor
is there in the whole World so generous and Prince-like a Quality as Oratory—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Prince-like, Pimp-like in sadness! I never knew as Orator that was not a Rascal, by the Mass: Orators are foolish flashy Coxcombs, of no sense or judgment, turn'd with every wind; they are never of the same opinion half an hour together, nor ever speak of the opinion they are of. Pox o'your Tropes and Flowers.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sir, upon my honour you mistake me still. I assure you I am a person—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Whom I hope to see hang'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: O Sir, you are in a merry humor: but, in good earnest, there is not a person in the whole World that is a greater admirer of your politer parts than my self.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Pshhaw! pox of admirers; pish! what care I whether you be or no. Prethee, pish! you are very troublesome, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Well Sir, you will have your pretty humors, you are dispos'd to be merry.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Merry! Oh your Jack-pudding! merry quoth a! wounds you lie—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sir, I have often intreated you to avoid passion, it drowns your parts, and obstructs the faculties of your mind, while a serene Soul, like that which I wear about me, operates clearly, notwithstanding the oppression of Clay, and the clog of my sordid humane Body.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness! would you were hang'd, that your serene Soul might be free from your sordid humane Body; 'tis a very sordid one, by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: O Sir, I will retire, and take away all occasions of your uttering things that re vera, are more injurious to your self, than reflecting on me. I take my leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p:
You do well in so doing, by the Mass. It's a fine life I live here: I am tormented with a couple of young ramping Sluts; and then there's my Nephew's Wife, the most impertinent foolish Creature breathing. Then my Nephew is such a Coxcomb, he has studi'd these twenty years about the natae of Lice, Spiders, and Insects; and has been as long compiling a Book of Geography for the World in the Moon Did he not give me my Board for nothing, in hopes of my Estate,
I'd not stay here— But above all Villaim, and tedious insipid Blockheads, this Sir Formal is the greatest; he is the most intollerable plague I have: I could—

lg.l: With any Fools but Orators dispense,
Who love words so, they never care for sense.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Longvil, Bruce, and Sir Samuel; (Sir Samuel in the habit of Longvil's Footman.)

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: WE are here to our wishes; and neither the Virtuoso, nor his Master of his Ceremonies within: If we could but meet with the Ladies now—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ay, if the Ladies were but here— you should see how I wou'd shew my parts. Whip-slap-dash. I'd come up roundly with A●…iranda, faith Boys— ha—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A pox o'this fellow, he'll be intollerable: I see there's no tempering with that Edge tool call'd a Fool—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I am disguis'd Cap a pe to all intents and purposes, and if any Man manages an Intriguo better than I, I will never hope for a Masquerade more, or expect to Dance my self again into any Lady's affection, and about that business. Come aloft, Sir Samuel, I say—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: But sweet Sir Samuel, if you discover your self, you will be turn'd out of the house, and we for company.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Let me alone; pox, if I should be discover'd, Ill bring you off as round as a hoop, in the twinkling of an Oyster-shell. But gad I cannot conceal my self from my Mistriss; my Love and Wit will break out now and then a little about the edges, or I shall burst, faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: wonder come the Ladies— Good Sam. keep your Distance.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: My distance! why the Ladies are by themselves; I'll present you to 'em, I'll introduce you. Come along, pull away, Boys. Now, my choice Lad●…. Hey poop, come aloft, Boy— Hah—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Do you hear, Sir Samuel, act the Footman a little better, or by Heav'n I'll turn you out-of my Livery.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What a pox, you are upon the High Ropes now. Prethee, Longvil, hold thy peace, with a whip-stich, your nose in my breech, I know what I have to do mun— Do you think to make a fool of Pil-garlick?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: By Heav'n, Pil-garlick, I'll cut your throat, if you advance beyond your post— Stand Centry there.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: If you do not, Sam. you'll find your Master very cholerick, honest Sam.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Cholerick! what a pox care I; how shall I shew my parts about this business? if I should stand here. Pshaw, Prithee hold thy peace—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Sirra, stand there, and mind your waiting— Damme stand still—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What a pox does he mean now? O'my Conscience and Soul he has been a drinking hard this morning, and is half-Seas over already.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Ladies your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: How long have we prayed to Heav'n for this opportunity of kissing your hands!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I see then you can be devout upon some occasions.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We shew'd our devotion sufficiently the first time we saw you; 'tin a Church Ladies—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Low! that it should be out 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 see you in a place so little us'd by you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I warrant they came hither as they do 〈◊〉 a Play-house, bolting out of some eating-house, having 〈◊〉 else to do in an idle after-noon.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis a wonder they do not come as the Sparks do to a Play-house too, full of Champagn, venting very much noise, and very little wit—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: What ever your intentions are, I am sure it is a very wicked thing for you to go to Church.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Why to seduce zealous young men, as we might have bin, but for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Your zeal will never do you hurt I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You for your part committed Sacriledge, and rob'd Heav'n of all my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: That's strange, for I assure you, none of mine e'r stray'd towards you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I am glad to find you can be so very zealous: They that can be so very violent in that higher sort of zeal, will often be so in a lower— I am glad to see my Mistriss violent in any passion; 'tis ten to one Love will have its turn then.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You could not but observe my great zeal to you, Madam; had I soar'd ne'r so high, you would have lured me down again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Alass, Sir, you never soar so high, but any lure will bring you down with a swoop, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You are he that have pester'd me with your Billets Doux: your fine little fashionable Notes ti'd with filk.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Yes, I have presented several Bills of Love upon you, and you would never make good payment of any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Would you have one answer a Bill of Love at sight? that's onely for substantial Traders: young Beginners dare not venture, they ought to be cautious.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Not, when they know him to be a responsable Merchant they have to deal with?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Such, who keep a correspondence with too many Factories, venture too much, and are in danger of breaking.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My Sister's in the right: 'Tis more danger trusting Love with such, than Money with Goldsmiths; especially considering most Men are apt to break in Womens debts. I have received several honorable Summons from you, if I would have accepted the Challenges.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I onely provok'd you fairly into the open Field; and 'gad, I wonder you had not honor enough to answer me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You would have drawn me into some wicked ambush or other, Matrimony or worse, I warrant you—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What a pox do these Fellows mean? I shall stand here till one of them has whipt away my Mistriss about business, with a Hixius Doxius, with the force of Repartee, and this, and that, and every thing in the world.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Why Sirra, Rascal!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis no matter for that Madam—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You impudent Dog.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Psha! psha! I care not a farthing for this. This is nothing, I am harden'd; I have been kill'd and beaten to all intents and purposes an hundred times, about intrigues and businesses▪ Madam, Madam, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What impudent sawcy footman's this?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Poor silly Rogue, he must be beaten into good manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ha-ha-ha, that's good i'faith! Poor silly Rogue! that's well. Ha-ha-ha. But all these kicks, and these businesses, and all that, we Men of Intrigue must bear. Prethee, Longvil, do not play the Fool; but let me discover my self—

sp.speaker: Longv
sp.p: Sirra, be gone, or I'll beat you most infinitely—

Madam, let us not trifle away those few happy minutes Fortune lends us Lovers. We know your streights, and how few opportunities we are like to have; and therefore let me tell you in short, I am most desperately in love with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: O Traitor! what says he? I must discover my self quickly about this business, or whip slap— I shall be bob'd of my Mistriss in the twinkling of a Bed-staff.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis true, our opportunities are like to be rare; but I'll improve this so well, we shall need no more— Good Sir, let it not transport you too much: for I do assure you, I am extremely and desperately out of love with you, and shall be so as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Say you so, Madam? and are you absolutely and violently resolv'd upon this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am glad to hear on't. I never knew a Woman absolutely resolve upon any thing, but she did the contrary.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I hope you'll not take example by your hard-hearted Sister, to nip so hopeful a Love in the Bud; but nourish it, and in time 'twill bring forth fruit worth the gathering.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It shall produce none for me, it's a dangerous surfeiting fruit, and I'l ha' none on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I'll sing a Song that I us'd to entertain 'em with, and that will discover me. I shall be even with these impudent Fellows.
sp.l: She tript like a Baron Do, &c.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what does this Rascal mean?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Pox on him; he sings worse than an old Woman a spinning.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How's this? I have heard that charming voice: 'tis very like a Coxcomb's that used to come hither, one Sir Samuel Hearty.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Peace, Envy, Peace, Coxcomb; she never was so much in the wrong in her life: she was always malicious against me, because I could not love her, poor Fool— Coxcomb, whip-stich, your Nose in my Breech.— Pish.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Hang him, let him discover himself.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis he sure— What project's this? he was ever a great Designer.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. Madam, you have lost your senses?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! this Rascal puts me beyond all patience. Impudent Villain—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it's no matter for that; it's no matter for that: I can bear any thing for my Mistriss. Don't you know me yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Tis he: I'll make as if I did not know him, and we'll have excellent sport with him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hold Sir; by your favor I am resolved to speak with him, and know the meaning of this.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Sirra.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Psha! prethee hold thy tongue, Tace is Latine for a Candle, I say again. I knew I shou'd screw her up to the tune of Love— Now do you know your faithful Servant Sir Samuel?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I do; but have a care, if my Sister discovers you, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I warrant you I'll be as secret as a Cockle.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am sorry you have been so exceedingly beaten and kick'd, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Psha! psha! it's nothing, nothing. Come, come— 'tis well it's no worse— Come, if any man in England out-does me in passive-valor about Intrigues, I am the son of a Tinder box—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Have a care, she suspects something—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ay, let me alone—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What sawcy impudent Footman's this? Correct his insolence, and send him hence, I like not his face—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The truth is, the Rascal is sawcy; but he'll learn better manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Good! how the Rogues Love makes her dissemble! Ah cunning Toad!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Sdeath you Dog! I'll learn you better manners; get you gone.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Pox on you, you over-act a Master, and kick too hard about business—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Do you hear▪ you nonsensical Owl, be gone out of the Garden, or by Heav'n I'll run my Sword in your guts—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Hold, Longvil, do not kill me; 'twill be something uncivil—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Uncivil! what a pox do you talk? Uncivil! why 'twill be murder mun. Uncivil quoth a— Well, I must be gone with a cup of Content, to the tune of a damn'd beating, or so— This is a fine nimble piece of business, that a Man cannot make love to his own Mistris. But I'll come upon him with a Quare impedit, and a good lusty cup of Revenge to boot—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We have discover'd your Fool. Do you want a Fool, that you must bring such a one as Sir Samuel along with you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Perhaps they thought themselves not able to divert us, and brought him to assist them—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Faith Ladies, if you make trial of us, if we be not able to divert you, you shall find us very willing.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I am sure if we do not divert you from your cruel resolutions, we are the most undone men that ever sigh'd, and look'd pale for Ladies, yet—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do not doubt but some Ladies, such as they are, may have made you look pale and wan.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But a civil Woman could never yet come near your hearts, or alter your faces.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: The greatest Generals do not scape always unwounded; you have done my business, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I have held out a long time against the Artillery of Ladies eyes; but a randome shot has maul'd me at last.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That cannot be; you were the greatest Mutineers against civil Women that could be.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Always shewing your parts against Matrimony, and defending the tawdry ill-bred fluttering Wenches o'the Town.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: That may be, Madam; but we are taken off.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Ay, Madam; we are taken off.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There's no trusting you; for though you seem to be taken off, as you call it, yet you'll stick fast to your good old Cause.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A Man often parts with his honesty, but never with his opinion for a Bribe—

div.stage: Enter L. Gimcrack and Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Mr. Bruce and Mr. Longvil in the Garden with my Nieces, say you! young Sluts! do they snap at all the Game that comes hither? what are they discoursing of?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why to the Tune of Love, Madam; what should young Gentlemen and Ladies talk of else?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O impudent Gill-flirts! cannot one young Gentleman scape 'em? Are they making Love to my Nieces, say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes, that they are, Madam, with a helter-skelter, whip-dash, as round as a hoop, what shou'd they do else? I'll retire—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: That's Mr. Bruce, a fine strait well-bred Gentleman, of a pleasing form, with a charming air in his face. The other, Mr. Longvil, who has a pleasing sweetness in his countenance, an agreeable straitness, and a grareful composure and strength in his Limbs. I am distracted in my choice on whom to fix my affection. Let me see, which shall I like best? Mr. Bruce is a fine person really, and so is Mr. Longvil: and so is Mr. Bruce I vow, and so is Mr. Longvil, I swear. In short, I like 'em both best, and these fluttering Sluts shall have none of 'em.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Prethee, Sister, let's change our Men, and then we shall be troubled with no love from 'em—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Agreed. But if we be, it is shifting of our torment, and that's some ease. But hold, we are undone: here's my Aunt.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servant. So, Nieces, you are soon acquainted with young Gentlemen, I see, It will in modesty befit you to retire.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We heard Sir Nicholas was at home, and took the liberty of a turn in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Where by accident we found these Ladies, who have done us the honor to entertain some discourse with us—

sp.speaker: L. Gio.
sp.p: They are always ready to shew their little or no breeding; you must pardon them they are raw Girls—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Thank Heav'n; we have not had the age and experience of your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: We will leave your Reverend Ladiship, to shew your great wisdom and breeding.

sp.speaker: L: Gim.
sp.p: How now, you pert Sluts——
Gentlemen, you are not to take notice what these idle Girls say concerning my age: for I protest, Gentlemen, I exceed not Twenty two, upon my Honor I do not.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: That's well; I remember her a Woman Twenty years ago.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Tis true.
'Tis impossible your Ladiship should be more.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You are in the very blossom of your age.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O Lord, Sirs! now, I swear, you do me too much honour. Yet had I not had some cares in the World, and the truth on't is, been marri'd somewhat against my will, I might have look'd much better. But 'tis no matter for that, I'm dispos'd of—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This is to let us know she does not care for her Husband.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: She means to trust one or both of us.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Yet I confess, Sir Nicholas is a fine solitary Philosophical person. But my nature more affects the vigorous gaity and jollity of Youth, than the fruitless speculations of Age.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Those fitter for your youth and blood. But may we not have the honor we were promised of seeing Sir Nicholas?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: The truth on't is, he is within, but upon some private business: but nothing shall be reserved from such accomplish'd persons as you are. The truth on't is, he's learning to swim.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Is there any Water hereabouts, Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: He does not learn to swim in the Water, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Not in the Water, Madam! how then?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: In his Laboratory, aspacious Room, where all his Instruments and fine Knacks are.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: How is this possible?

sp.speaker: L. Gim
sp.p: Why he has a Swiming-Master comes to him.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: A Swiming-Master! this is beyond all president— He is the most curious Coxcomb breathing—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: He has a Frog in a Bowl of Water, ty'd with a pack-thred by the loins; which pack-thred Sir Nicholas holds in his teeth, lying upon his belly on a Table; and as the Frog strikes, he strikes; and his swiming-Master stands by, to tell him when he does well or ill.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This is the rarest Fop that ever was heard of.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Few Virtuoso's can arrive to this pitch, Madam. This is the most curious invention I ever heard of.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Alas! he has many such He is a rare Mechanick Philosopher. The Colledge indeed refus'd him, they envy'd him.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Were it not possible to have the favor of seeing this Experiment?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I cannot deny any thing to such persons. I'll introduce you.

div.stage: SCENE opens, and discovers Sir Nicholas learning to swim upon a Table, Sir Formal and the Swiming-Master standing by.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: In earnest this is very fine: I doubt not, Sir, but in a short space of time, you will arrive at that curiosity in this watery Science, that not a Frog breathing will exceed you. Though I confess it is the most curious of all amphibious Animals (in the Art, shall I say, or rather nature of Swiming.)

sp.speaker: Swim. Must.
sp.p: Ah! well struck, Sir Nicholas; that was admirable, that was as well swom as any Man in England can. Observe the Frog, Draw up your Arms a little nearer, and then thrust 'em out strongly— Gather up your Legs a little more— So, very well—— Incomparable—

div.stage: Enter Bruce, Longvil, and L. Gimcrack.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let's not interrupt them, Madam, yet but observe a little this great Curiosity.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Tis a noble Invention.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: 'Tis a thing the Colledge never thought on.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Let me rest a little to respire. So it is wonderful, my noble Friend, to observe the agility of this pretty Animal, which, notwithstanding I impede its motion, by the detention of this Filum or Thred within my teeth, which makes a ligature about its loins, and though by many sudden stops I cause the Animal sometimes to sink or immerge, yet with indefatigable activity it rises and keeps almost its whole body upon the superficies or surface of this humid Element—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
True, Noble Sir; nor do I doubt but your Genius
will make Art equal, if not excced Nature; nor will this or any other Frog upon the face of the Earth out-swim you—

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Nay, I doubt not, Sir, in a very little time to become amphibious; a man, by Art, may appropriate any Element to himself. You know a great many Virtuoso's that can fly; but I am so much advanc'd in the Art of Flying, that I can already out fly that pond'rous Animal call'd a Bustard; nor should any Grey-hound in England catch me in the calmest day, before I get upon wing: Nay, I doubt not, but in a little time to improve the Art so far, 'twill be as common to buy a pair of Wings to fly to the World in the Moon, as to buy a pair of Wax Boots to ride into Sussex with.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Nay doubtless, Sir, if you proceed in those swift gradations you have hitherto prosper'd in, there will be no difficulty in the noble enterprise, which is devoutly to be effligated by all ingenious persons since the intelligence with that Lunary World wou'd be of infinite advantage to us, in the improvement of our Politicks.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Right: for the Moon being Domina humidiorum, to wit, the Governess of moist Bodies, has, no doubt, the superior Government of all Islands; and its influence is the cause so many of us are Dilirious and Lunatick in this. But having sufficiently refrigerated my lungs by way of respiration, I will return to my swiming—

sp.speaker: Swim. Mast.
sp.p: Admirably well struck! rarely swum! he shall swim with any man in Europe.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Hold, Sir Nicholas; here are those Noble Gentlemen and Philosophers, whom I invited to kiss your hands; and I am not a little proud of the honor, of being the grateful and happy Instrument of the necessitude and familiar communication which is like to intervene between such excellent Virtuoso's.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We are, Sir Nicholas's, and your most humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We shall think our selves much honored with the knowledge of so celebrated a Virtuoso.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You are right welcome into my poor Laboratory; and if in ought I can serve you in the way of Science my nature is diffusive, and I shall be glad of communicating with such eminent Virtuoso's as I am let to know you are.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We pretend to nothing more than to be your humbl admirers.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉.
sp.p: All the ingenions World are proud of Sir Nicholas, for his Physico-mechanical Excellencies.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: I confess I have some felicity that way; but were I as praecelling in Physico-Mechanical Investigations, as you in Tropical Rhetorical Flourishes, I wou'd yield to none.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: How the Asses claw one another?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We are both your admirers. But of all quaint Inventions, none ever came near this of Swiming.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Truly I opine it to be a most compendious method, that in ●… fortnights prosecution has advanced him to be the best Swimer 〈◊〉 Europe. Nay, if it were possible to swim with any Fish of his Inches.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Have you ever tri'd in the Water, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I swim most exquisitely on Land.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Do you intend to practise in the Water, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Never, Sir; I hate the Water, I never come upon the Water, Sir.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Then there will be no use of Swiming.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I content my self with the Speculative part of Swiming, I care not for the Practick. I seldom bring any thing to use, 'tis not my way. Knowledge is my ultimate end.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You have reason, Sir; Knowledge is like Virtue, its own reward.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: To study for use is base and mercenary, below the serene and quiet temper of a sedate Philosopher,

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You have hit it right, Sir. I never studi'd any thing for use but Physick, which I administer to poor people: you shall see my method.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you, what new curiosities have you found out in Physick?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Why I have found out the use of Respiration, or Breathing, which is a motion of the Thorax and the Lungs, whereby the Air is impell'd by the Nose▪ Mouth▪ and Windpipe into the Lungs, and thence expell'd farther to elaborate the Blood, by refrigerating it, and separating its fuliginous steams.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What a secret the Rogue has found out?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I have found too, that an Animal may be preserv'd without respiration, when the wind-pipe's cut in two, by follicular impulsion of Air; to wit, by blowing wind with a pair of bellows into the Lungs.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have heard of a Creature preserv'd by blowing wind in the Breech, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: That's frequent. Besides, tho' I confess, I did not invent it, I have performed admirable effects by transfusion of Blood; to wit, by putting the Blood of one Animal into another.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my integrity he has advanc'd transfusion to the Achme of perfection, and has the Ascendent over all the Virtuosi in point of that Operation. I saw him do the most admirable effects in the World upon two Animals; the one a Domestick Animal▪ commonly call'd a Mangy Spaniel; and a less Fame●…lick Creature, commonly call'd a Sound Bull-Dog. Be pleas'd, Sir to 〈◊〉 it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 I made, Sir, both the Animals to be Emittent and Recipient 〈◊〉 the same time, after I had made Ligatures as hard I 〈◊〉, for fear of strangling the Animals, to render the 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, I open'd the Carotid Arteries, and Jugular 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 at one time, and so caus'd them to change Blood 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 another.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉.
sp.p: Indeed that which ensu'd upon the Operation was miraculous; for the mangy Spaniel became sound, and the sound Bull-dog mangy.

sp.speaker: Sir Nec.
sp.p: Not only so, Gentlemen, but the Spaniel became a Bull-dog, and the Bull-dog a Spaniel.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Which considering the civil and ingenuous temper and education of the Spaniel, with the rough and untaught savageness and ill-breeding of the Bull-dog, may not undeservedly challenge the name of a Wonder.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Tis an Experiment you'll deserve a Statue for.

div.stage: Enter Clarinda, Miranda, and Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, I must beg your pardon for my intrusion: but I have found out such a practise upon my Sister, as will nearly concern you to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What does she mean now?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Against Miranda, say you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This Foot-man has brought a Letter, and has been tempting her from that vile Man Sir Samuel Hearty. There 'tis.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for her persecution. Be confident of me, you can endure any thing—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ay, any thing, the most substantial beating under the Sun. I have had a pretty parcel o' kicks already about this business: but as long as I find love, I care not for ●…icking.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A pox o' this Rascal, he'll undo us—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: This is a Villain indeed, to tempt my Niece from that Knight; why he is a Spark, a Gallant, a Wit o'th' Town; the greatest debaucher of Youth, and corrupter of Ladies in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: The Rogue has hit me to a Cows thumb, he's as cunning a Fellow as any within forty shillings of his head.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: The Man indeed has spruce, polite, Mercurial, and pretty concise parts; but he's a little too volatile and flashy; he would make a fine person if he were but solid.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Good! solid! wou'd he so? That's as dull a Fellow as a man would wish to lay his leg over.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I confess he is my Foot-man, but shall be no longer so; let him be soundly pump'd and toss'd in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Truly it is an injury beyond all sufferance, and with your leave, I'll have him so exercis'd. Call in my people.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir! what do you mean? Sir Samuel desired me to deliver this Note; and he's a person I am much beholding to, that's all I know o'th' matter, only that he is a fine Gentleman, and a witty facetious person as any wears a head.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Here! where are my Servants!
Sirra! strip that Rascal's Coat over his ears.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Longvil! what are you mad? I shall catch cold in the twinkling of a Bedstaff, man.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Do you hear, let him be taken, and first pumpt soundly, and then toss'd in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Impudent Rascal! away with him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pump him soundly impudent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ah, my pretty little dissembling Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: See it done to purpose, and then turn him out a doors.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: What a Devil shall I do? but she loves me still. Come— 'tis well it's no worse— my intrigue goes on rarely—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let's see the execution.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come on let's see how generously he suffers.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: But now to return to my transfusion.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: That was a rare Experiment of transfusing the blood of a Sheep into a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Short of many of mine. I assure you I have transfus'd into a humane Vein 64 ounces Haver du pois weight, from one Sheep. The emittent Sheep dy'd under the Operation, but the recipient Mad-man is still alive; he suffer'd some disorder at first. The Sheep's blood being Heterogeneous, but in a short time it became Homogeneous with his own.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Ha! Gentlemen, was not this incomparable? but tyou shall hear more.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: The Patient from being Maniacal, or raging mad, became wholly Ovine or Sheepish; he bleated perpetually, and chew'd the Cud: he had Wool growing on him in great quantities, and a Northamptonshire Sheep's Tail did soon emerge or arise from his Anus or humane Fundament.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness Nephew, I am asham'd of you, you will never leave Lying and Quacking with your Transfusions and Fools tricks. I believe if the blood of an Ass were transfused into a Virtuoso, you would not know the emittent Ass from the Recipient Philosopher, by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O Uncle! you'll have your way; he's a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Pox! merry! prithee leave prating and lying; I am not merry, I am angry with such Coxcombs as you are.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you are very pleasant, and will have your facetious pretty humors.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: You are the Zany to this Mountebank.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Pray, Uncle, interrupt us not. To convince you Gentlemen, of the truth of what I say, here is a Letter from the Patient, who calls himself the meanest of my Flock, and sent me some of his own Wool. I shall shortly have a Flock of 'em; I'll make all my Clothes of 'em, 'tis finer than Beaver. Here was one to thank me for the Cure by Sheeps blood just now—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: O yes! he did not speak, but bleated his thanks to you. In sadness you deserve to be hang'd▪ You kill'd four or five that I know with your transfusion—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Sir, alass! those men suffer'd not under the Operation, but they were Cacochymious, and had deprav'd Viscera, that is to say, their Bowels were gangren'd.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p:
Pish! I do not know what you mean by your damn'd Cacochymious canting; but they dy'd in sadness. Prethee make
hast with your canting and lying, and let's go to dinner, or you shall quack by your self——

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A pleasant blunt old Fellow—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: He's in the wrong in abusing Transfusion: for excellent Experiments may be made in changing one Creature into the nature of another.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Nay, it may be improved to that height, to alter the flesh of Creatures that we eat, as much as grafting and inoculating does Fruits—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, I do it, I use it to that end.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Pox! let me see you invent any thing so useful as a Mousetrap, and I'll believe some of your Lies. Prethee! did not a fellow cheat thee with Eggs, which he pretended were laid with hairs in them, and you gave him ten shillings apiece for the Eggs; till I discover'd they were put in at a hole, made by a very fine Needle.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Well Mr. Snarl, you have the prettiest way of drolling. Gentlemen, pray let me recommend him to you, he's a fine facetious witty person indeed.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: You recommend me! Prethee, damn'd Orator, hold thy tongue. In sadness you are a foolish flashy Fellow—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We shall be glad of the honour to know you.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I desire no acquaintance with any young Man of this Age, nor I.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Why so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Why then are vitious illiterate foolish Fellows, good for nothing but to roar and make a noise in a Play-house. To be very brisk with pert Whores in Vizards, who, though never so ill-bred, are most commonly too hard for them at their own weapon, Repartee— And when Whores are not there, they play Monkey-tricks with one another, while all sober men laugh at them.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: They are even with them, for they laugh at all sober men again.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: No Man's happy but by comparison. 'Tis the great comfort of all the World to despise and laugh at one another.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: But these are such unthinking Animals, and so weary of themselves, they can never be alone; always complaining of short life, yet never know what to do with the time they have.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This snarling Fellow's sometimes in the right.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Their top of their Education is to sma●…er French: for in France they have been to learn French Vices to spend English Estates with; with an insipid gaity, which is to be slight and bright, very pert and very dull.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Sir I beseech you to be civiller to my Friends.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I am transported with passio n against the young Fellows of the Age.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Old Fools always envy young Fools.

sp.speaker: Snarl,
sp.p: they are all forward and positive in things they understand not; they laugh at any Gentleman that has Art or Science, and make it the property of a well bred Gentleman, to be good for nothing, but to make a Figure in the Drawing-room, set his Periwig in the Glass, smile, whisper, and make legs and foolish faces for an hour or two, without one word of sense in sadness.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: The snarling Rogue's very tart upon the Youngsters.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: When the pleasures of Wine and Women, the joys of Youth leaves us, Envy and Malice the lusts of Age, succed 'em—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Besides, they are all such Whoring fellows, in sadness ●… am asham'd of 'em. The last Age was an Age of Modesty—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I believe there was the same Wenching then: onely they dissembled it. They added Hypocrasie to Fornication, and so made two Sins of what we make but one.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: After all his virtue, this old Fellow keeps a Whore. I▪ ll tell you more on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Nil.
sp.p: I hope you will pardon the rough nature of my Uncle, who spares no body. Now if you please, Gentlemen, we'll retire. I am sorry I cannot perform the dissection of the Lobster, which I promis'd. My Fish-monger that serves me for that Operation, has fail'd me: but I'll assure you it is the most curious of all Testaceous or Crustaceous Animals whasoever.

sp.speaker: Sir 〈◊〉.
sp.p: But we will read an Author, and sport about a little Grek and Latine before Dinner. The one is a noble refection of the Mind, as the other is of the Body.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: After Dinner we will have a Lecture concerning the Nature of Insects, and will survey my Microscopes, 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉, Pneumatick Engines, Stentrophonical Tubes, and the like—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We are infinitely oblig'd to you, Sir. But all this does not edifie with our Mistresses, Longvil.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We must find a way to get rid of these insipid Fools. I have a way to get rid of the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we most humbly attend your motions.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We wait on you.

div.head: ACT. III.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: DEar Madam! tender the life and welfare of a poor humble Lover.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What a fashionable Gentleman of this Age, and a Lover! it is impossible! They are all Keepers, and 〈◊〉 tawdry things from the Exchange or the Play-house, and make the poor Creatures run mad with the extremity of the alteration; as a young Heir, being kept short, does at the death of his Father.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I was never one of those Madam: nothing but age and impotence can reduce me to that condition. I had 〈◊〉 kill my own Game, than send to a Poulterers. Besides, I never eat Tame things, when wild of the same kind are in season. I hate your coopt cramb'd Lady; I love 'em as they go about, as I do your Barn-door Fowl.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis more natural indeed.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But had I been ne'r so wicked, you have made such an absolute whining Convert of me, that forgetting all shame and reproach from the Wits and Debauchees of the Town, I can be a Martyr for Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Lord! that you should not take warning! Have not several of your married Friends, like those upon the Ladder, bidden all good people take warning by them.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: For all that, neither Lovers nor Malefactors can take it; one will make experiment of Mariage, and th'other of Hanging at their own sad costs. Neither of the Executions will e er be left off.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: They are both so terrible to Women, 'tis hard to know which to chuse.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: If you Ladies were willing, we Men are apt to be civil upon easier terms.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No; those terms are harder than the other.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You are so nimble, a Man knows not which way to catch you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Once for all I assure you, I will never be catch'd any way by you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
