sp.p: Do not provoke Love thus, lest he should revenge his cause, and make you doat upon some nauseous Coxcomb, whom all the Town scorns.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Let Love do what it will, I neither dare nor will talk on't any longer.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You are afraid of talking of Love, as some are of reading in a Coujuring-book, for fear it should raise the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What ever you can say, will as soon raise one as the other in me. But I must take leave of you and your Similies. My Uncle will want you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Will you not in charity afford me one interview more this after-noon?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Provided I hear not one word of Love, and my Uncle and Aunt be secure; I shall be in the Walk on the East-side of the Garden an hour hence. But, by your leave, I shall meet another there—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A thousand thanks for the honour. Yonder come Bruce and Clarinda; I'll retire—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I have taken more pains to single you out, than ever Wood-man did for a Deer.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If the Wood-man were no better a Marks-man, the Deer would be safe for all his singling. Besides, I am not so tame to stand a shot yet, I thank you—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Lovers are quick Aimers, and can shoot flying.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Not, if they fly so fast as I shall from you.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p:
Come, I see this way will not do: I'll try another with you. Ah, Madam! change your cruel intentions, or I shall become the most desolate Lover, that ever yet, with arms across, sigh'd to a murmuring Grove, or to a purling Stream complain'd. Savage! I'll wander up and down the Woods, and carve my
passion on the Barks of Trees, and vent my grief to winds, that as they fly shall sigh and pity me▪

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now! what foolish Fustian's this? you talk like an Heroick Poet.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Since the common down-right way of speaking sense would not please you, I had a mind to try what the Romantick way of wining Love cou'd do.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No more of this, I had rather hear the tatling of Gossips at an Upsitting, or Christning, nay, a Phanatick Sermon, or, which is worse than all, a dull Rhiming Play, with nothing in't but lewd Hero's huffing against the Gods.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Why, I'll try any sort of Love to please you, Madam; I▪ ll shew you that of a gay Coxcombe; with his full plumes, strutting and rustling about his Mistriss, like a Turky-cock, baiting her with brisk aiery motion, and fashionable nonsence, thinking to carry her by dint of Periwig and Garniture, or by changing some pretty foolish sonnet of Phillis or Coelis; or at best, treating her with nothing but ends of Plays, or second-hand Jests, which he runs on tick with witty men for, and is never able to pay them again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, there are too many of these fine Sparks you talk of, who perhaps may be very clinquant, slight and bright, and make a very pretty show at first; but the Tincel-Gentleman do so tarnish in the wearing, there's no enduring them.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: But I am of good metall, Madam, and so true, that I shall abide any Touch-stone, even that of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But it's an ill-bargain, where I must buy my Metal first, and touch it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You shall touch it first, Madam, and if you do not like it, I'll take it again and no harm done.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No: I'll take care there shall be no harme done▪ Pray divert this unseasonable Discourse of Love, for I will never hear on't more. Farewell, I see my Lady Gimcrack in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let me but beg to have one Treaty more with you this afternoon: if I convince you not of the error of your hard heart, I must submit and be miserable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: If you love to hear the same thing again, I will declare it to you an hour hence in the green Walk on the other side the Wilderness— Farewel— But, by your leave, you shall find another in my place—

div.stage: Enter Lady Gimcrack at another door.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Your Ladiship's humble Servant. I have been taking the fresh air in the Garden, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I am come with the same intention, and am happy in the company of a person, who is so much a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Your Ladiship does me too much honour.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, your accomplishments command respect from all Ladies. I doubt not but you have been happy in many Ladies affections—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What will this come to?—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: But Women will be frail, while there are such persons in the world, that's most certain.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Your Ladiship's in a merry humor, to rally a poor young Gentleman thus.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Far be it from me, I swear; your perfections are so prevalent, that were I not in honour engag'd unto Sir Nicholas (and Honour has the greatest Ascendent in the World upon me) I assure you I wou'd not venture my self alone with such a person: But Honour's a great matter, a great thing, I'll vow and swear.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You Ladies will abuse your humble Servants; we are born to suffer.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, that you shou'd take me to be in jest! I swear I am in earnest, and were I not sure of my Honor, that never fail'd me in a doubtful occasion, I would not give you this opportunity of tempting my frailty; not but that my virtuous inclinations are equal with any Ladies: but there is a prodigious Witch-craft in opportunity. But honor does much, yet opportunity is a great thing, I swear a great thing.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, if we use it when it offers it self.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: How Sir! ne'r hope for't! ne'r think on't! I wou'd not for all the World I protest. Let not such thoughts of me enter into your head. My honour will protect me. I make use of an opportunity— I am none of those I assure you.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! how apprehensive she is? I shall forget the Speculative part of Love with Clarinda, and fall to the practick with her. But I shall ne'r hold out that long journey, without this or some other bait by the way.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p:
Yet, as I was saying, opportunity's a bewitching thing▪ Let all Ladies beware of opportunity, I say,: for alass, if we
were not innocent and virtuous now▪ what use might we make of this opportunity now?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: She's so damnably affected, and silly, 'twou'd pall any one's appetite but mine. Folly and affection are as nauseous as deformity.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Should we now retire into that cool Grotto for refreshment, the censorious world might think it strange; but honour will preserve me. Honour's a rare thing, I swear, I defie temptation.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You'll not give a man leave to trouble you with much. I have not observ'd that Grotto; shall I wait on you to survey it.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Ay Sir, with all my heart to survey that; but if you have any wicked intentions, I'll swear you'll move me prodigiously. If your intentions be dishonorable, you'll provoke me strangely.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Try me, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Hold! hold! have a care what you do. I will not try if you be not sure of your Honor. I'll not venture, I protest.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What ever you are of mine, you are sure of your own.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Right, that will defend me. Now tempt what you will though we go in, nay, though we shut the door too: I fear nothing; it's all one to me as long as I have my Honour about me. Come.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Yonder comes Longvil, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake remove from me, or he'll suspect my Honour.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: So, this accident has preserv'd me honest. I am as constant a Lover as any man in England, when I have no oppotunity to be otherwise—

sp.speaker: L. Gim▪
sp.p: Fa-la-la-la▪ O me Sir 〈◊〉 swear▪ you frighted me▪ I protest my heart was at my mouth. Alass! I shall nor recover the disorder a good while.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mad●…?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: You brought a Gentleman that's 〈◊〉 so fresh into my mind, one 〈◊〉 was the first Object of my 〈◊〉 and Affections, not 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 see you 〈◊〉. 〈◊〉 I thought it had been his Ghost, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I am happy in resembling any one you could love, Madam

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I have long forgotten my passion for him; but the sight of you did stir in me a strange Jè ne scai quoi towards you; and but that I am another's now— otherwise— But I say too much.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have been too much acquainted with her character to doubt her meaning. Madam, you honour me so much, I cannot acknowledge it enough by my words, my hearty actions shall speak my thanks.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Actions! Oh Heav'n! what actions? I hope you mean honourably. I swear you brought all the blood of my body into my face. Actions, said you! I hope you are a person of honour, my Honour's dearer to me than the whole Word. I would not violate my Reputation for the whole Earth.

sp.speaker: Longv▪
sp.p: Let us retire, Madam. If I do not shew my self a Man of Honour, may your Ladiship renounce me.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Retire! Heav'n forbid! Are we not private enough? W●…ll, you put me more and more in mind of my first Love, I swear you do.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: By your leave, Miranda, I can hold no longer. Though I am as true as Steel, any handsome Woman will strike fire on me. Let us repose a while in the Grotto, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O Heav'n, Sir! do not tempt me. What, give my self an opportunity! Consider my Honour, Sir; I am another's▪

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: And shall be so still; Madam, whatsoever use I shall make of your Ladiship, I shall return you again, and ne'r alter the property. Dear Madam, retire.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir! what do you mean? you fright me so, I protest my heart is at my mouth. I am no such person. Dear Sir, mistake me not, misconstrue not my freedome; I wou'd not for the World— Well, I swear you are to blame now, mever 〈◊〉 you are— But 'tis your first fault, I can forgive you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I am sorry I have offended. But let us retire into the Grotto, and I'll make as many acknowledgments as I can.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you are a little more civil, I am con●… for discourse sake, for I love discourse mightily—

sp.speaker: Longv▪
sp.p: W●…l, I 〈◊〉 a 〈◊〉▪ Dear Miranda, forgive me this once. Come, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I'll follow. But d'ye hear, Sir, if you be the least uncivil, upon my honour I'll cry out. Remember, Sir, I give you warning. Do not think on't, I swear and vow I will; do not, I say, do not.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: No, no, I warrant you; I'll trust you for that. How fearful she is I should not think on't?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Longvil, Sir Nicholas Gimcrack desires your noble presence: ●…e being now ready to impart those secrets about Insects, which I dare be bold to say, no Virtuoso, Domestick or Foreign, has explor'd but himself.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I humbly kiss your Ladiship's fair hands.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Shame on this unlucky Fellow: I have discover'd the cross love between my Nieces and these Gentlemen, and will make work with it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, here's a Letter for your Ladiship; the Messenger would deliver it to none but me.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Ha! it is from my dear Hazard.
Madam, I am extremely impatient to see your Ladiship at 〈◊〉 old place of assignation, as well for a great deal of Love, as for a little Business.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Well, I will go, though it cost me money. I know that's his little business. I know not why we Ladies should not keep as well as Men sometimes. But I shall neglect my important affair with these two fine sweet persons. But that's uncertain, this is sure.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: How happy am I in thy Love! here I can find retreat, when tir'd with all the Rogues and Fools in Town.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Ay, Dearest! come to thine own Miss; she loves thee, Buddy, poor Buddy. Coachee, coachee.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: O my poor Rogue. But when didst thou see thy Friend▪ Mrs. Flirt, my Nephew Gimcrack's Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: O shame on her! out upon her! O name her not.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Bird?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: O filthy Creature, I cannot abide her▪ she's 〈◊〉 she's naught.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Figg? what has she done to thee?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Done! I'll never forgive her while ●… ha'breath. Do not speak of her, she's a base Creature; name her not, I ha'done with her.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Has she affronted thee, poor Rogue? I'll have her maul'd. Filthy Creature.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Ay, birds-nyes, she's a Quean. But do not thee trouble thy self with her; 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I will know what she has done to thee. In sadness, if you do not tell me, I won't love thee, Pigs-nie.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Well, I will, but won't you laugh at me then?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: No, by the Mass, not I.

sp.speaker: Fig
sp.p: Nay, but thou wilt, Bird.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness I won't.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Why would you think it? I wish I might ne'r stir out o'this place, if the lewd Carrion had not the impudence to tell me, that Sir Nicholas Gimcrack was a handsomer Man than thou art. No, I'll ne'r forgive her while I ha've breath.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Poor Rogue! thou art a dear Creature in sadness.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Impudent Flirts! but I swear our Sex grows so vicious and infamous, I am asham'd of 'em, they have no modesty in 'em.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness it's a very wicked Age; men make no conscience o'their ways, by the Mass. In the last Age we were modest and virtuous, we spent our time in making visits, and playing at Cards with the Ladies, so civil so virtuous, and well-bred.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: For my part, I blush at the impudent Creatures of the Town, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: So do I, in sadness. To see Villains wrong their sweet Wives, and, while they keep them short, let little dowdy Strumpets spend their Estates for 'em, by the Mass my heart bleeds, to see so great a decay of Conjugal affection in the Nation.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Out upon 'em, filthy Wenches; I wonder they dare shew their harden'd faces. They are so bold, 'tis a burning shame they should be suffer'd I vow.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p:
Nay, the young Coxcombs are worse; nothing but swearing, drinking, whoring, tearing, ranting, and roaring.
In sadness I shou'd be weary of the world for the vices of it, but that thou comfort'st me sometimes, Buddy.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Numps, talk no more of 'em; I spit at 'em; but I love n'own Buddy Mun. Predee kiss me.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ah poor Budd, poor Rogue! we are civil now; what harm's in this?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: None, none. Poor Dear, kiss again, Mun.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ah poor thing. In sadness thou shalt have this Purse; nay, by the Mass thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Na●… p●…sh! I cannot abide the money, not I▪ I love thee, thou art a civil, discreet, sober person of the last Age.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ah poor little Rogue! in sadness I'ill bite thee by the lip, i'faith I will. Thou hast incenc'st me strangely, thou hast fir'd my blood, I can bear it no longer, i'faith I cannot. Where are the instruments of our pleasure? Nay, prethee do not frown, by the Mass thou shalt do't now.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: I wonder that should please you so much, that pleases me so little?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I was so us'd to't at Westminster-School, I cou'd never leave it out since.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Well: look under the Carpet then if I must.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Very well, my dear Rogue. But dost hear, thou art too gentle. Do not spare thy pains. I love Castigation mightily— So, here's good provision.

div.stage: [Pulls the Carpet, three or four great Rods fall down.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Ho there within! open the door. 'Sdeath I'll break it open. What Rascal have you got with you? I'll maul him.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: O Heav'n! this Rascal will undo me. What shall I do? 'Tis my Brother.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness I shall be ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Run, run, if you love me, into the Wood-hole quickly. I'll get rid of him. For Heaven's sake take the Birch along with you

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ah Hectoring Rascal! we had none o'this in the last Age. Rogues! Dogs! A man cannot be in private with a Sister, but he must be disturb'd by th'impertinent Brother, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: In! in! I'll out to him—

div.p: Sir Nicholas, Sir Formal▪ Bruce, Longvil:

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
I do assure you, Gentlemen, no man upon the 〈◊〉
of the earth is so well seen in the Nature of Ants, Flies, Humble-Bees, Ear-wigs, Millepedes, Hogs-Lice, Maggots, Mites in a Cheese, Todpoles, Worms, Neufts, Spiders, and all the noble products of the Sun, by equivocal Generation.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Indeed, I ha' found more curious Phoenomina in these minute Animals, than in those of vaster magnitude.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I take the Ant to be a most curious Animal.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: More curious than all Oviperous or Egg-laying Creatures in the whole World. There are three sorts, Black, Dark-brown, and Fillamot.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: The Black will pinch the Dark-brown with his forceps, till it kills it upon the place; the like will the Dark-brown do by the Fillamot— I have dissected their Eggs upon the object plate of a Microscope, and find that each has within it an included Ant, which has adhering to its Anus or Fundament, a small black speck, which becomes a Vermicle, like a Mite, which I have watched whole days and nights; and Sir Formal has watch'd 'em thirty hours together.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A very pretty employment.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: And a long time we cou'd find no motion, but that of Flexion and Extension: but at last it becomes an Ant, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What does it concern a Man to know the nature of an Ant?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: O it concerns a Virtuoso mightily: so it be Knowledge, 'tis no matter of what.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir, I take 'em to be the most politick of all Insects.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: You have hit it, Gentlemen▪ they have the best Government in the World: What do you opine it to be?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: O! a Common-wealth most certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Worthy Sir, I see you are a great Observer; it is a Republick resembling that of the States-General.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Undoubtedly! and the Dutch are just such industrious and busie Animals.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Right. But now I beseech you be pleas'd to communicate some of your quainter Observations to these Philosophers, about those subtil and insidious Animals call'd Spiders.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p:
I think I have found out more Phoenomena's or Appearances of Nature in Spiders, than any Man breathing:
Wou'd you think it? there are in England six and thirty sevèral sorts of Spiders; there's your Hound, Grey-hound, Lurcher, Spaniel Spider.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But, above all, your Tumbler-Spider is most admirable.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O Sir, I am no Stranger to't: it catches flies as Tumblers do Conies.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Good! how these Fools will meet a lie half-way.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Great Lyars are always civil in that point; as there is no lie too great for their telling, so there's none too great for their believing.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: The Fabrick or Structure of this Insect, with its Texture, is most admirable.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Nor is its Sagacity, or Address, less to be wonder'd at, as I have had the honour to observe under my noble Friend; as soon as it has spi'd its Prey, as suppose upon a Table, it will crawl underneath till it arrive to the Antipodes of the Fl●…, which it discovers by sometimes peeping up; and if the capricious Fly happens not to remove it self by crural motion, or the vibration of its wings, it makes a fatal leap upon the heedless prey, of which, when it has satisfied its appetite, it carries the remainder to its Cell, or Hermitage.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: It will teach its young ones to hunt, and discipline 'em severely when they commit faults; and when an old one misses its Préy, it will retire, and keep its Chamber for grief, shame and anguish, ten hours together.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my integrity it is true, for I have several times, by Sir Nicholas's command watched the Animal, upon this or the like miscarriages.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: But, Sir, there is not in the World a more docible Creature, I have kept several of 'em tame.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: That's curious indeed▪ I never heard of a tame Spider before.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: One above all the rest, I had call'd him Nick, and he knew his name so well, he wou'd follow me all over the house▪ I fed him indeed with fair Flesh-flies. He was the best natur'd, best condition'd Spider, that ever I met with. You knew Nick very well, Sir Formal, he was of the Spaniel breed, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Knew him! I knew Nick intimately well▪

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: These Fools are beyond all that Art or Nature e'r produc'd.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: These are the admirable Secrets they find out—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Have you observed that delicate Spider call'd Tarantula?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Now you have hit me, now you come home to me; why I travell'd all over Italy, and had no other affair in the world, but to study the secrets of that harmonious Insect.

sp.speaker: Bruce
sp.p: Did you not observe the Wisdom, Policies, and Customs of that ingenious people?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Oh by no means! 'Tis below a Virtuoso, to trouble himself with Men and Manners. I study Insects; and I have observ'd the Tarantula, does infinitely delight in Musick, which is the reason of its poison being drawn out by it. Ther's your Phaenomenon of Sympathy!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Does a Tarantula delight so in Musick?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Oh extravagantly. There are three sorts, Black, Grey and Red, that delight in three several sorts and modes of Musick.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: That was a curious Inquisition; how did you make it?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Why I put them upon three several Chips in water, then caused a Musician to play, first a grave Pavin, or Almain, at which the black Tarantula onely mov'd; it danc'd to it with a kind of grave motion, much like the Benchers at the Revels.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, The Gentleman that's going for Lapland, Russia, and those parts, is come for your Letters and Queries which you are to send thither.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I'll wait on him. I keep a constant correspondence with all the Virtuoso's in the North and North-East parts. There are rare Phaenomena's in those Countrys. I am beholding to Finland, Lapland, and Russia, for a great part of my Philosophy. I send my Queries thither. Come, Sir Formal, will you help to dispatch him?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I am proud to serve you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to take a turn in the Garden. When we have dispatch'd, we will impart more of our Microscopical 〈◊〉.
Your humble Servant— This is a happy deliverance.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have remov'd the Lady by writing to Hazard, to send for her, and keep her an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: And I have sent my man to find out Sir Nicholas his Strumpet, as soon as he has found her, she'll send for him.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: For all his Vertue and Philosophy. This grave Fool will be in the fashion too. Now if we can get rid of this wordy Fool Sir Formal, we have the Ladies to our selves. In the mean time, let's to our several and respective assignations.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What shall I say to this Bruce? Oh unjust Custom! that has made Women but passive in Love, as if Nature had intended us for Cyphers onely, to make up the number of the Creation.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Yonder's my Clarinda: Now Love inspire me, I am infinitely transported with this honour you do me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If I have done you any honor, pray make your best on't.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Is it you, Madam? this honour was unexpected.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why whom did you expect? O I see you are not so much transported as you thought you were.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: The honor of your Ladiships company I did not expect.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nor much care for, I see.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Twere Blasphemy if I should say so. 'Twas your Sister I expected.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: My Sister! so, I am not fit for your company it seems.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: If I wou'd tell you how I prize the honour, I shou'd invade the interest of my Friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your Friend! if you had no more interest in him, than I am resolv'd he shall ever have in me: he'd be the worst Friend you have.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: He's a Man of Honour, and of Wealth: and if any man cou'd deserve you, he might.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The World is not so barren, but I have found a fitter man: but, Sir, 'twas not my Sister; 'twas my Lady Gimcrack you hop'd to meet here. You are a Man of Honor. The Grotto is a fine Scene of Love. The Lady not very unwilling, 'twas well you were interrupted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! how came she to know that? but I must bear it out; I cannot ghess your meaning: but I see you love your Sister well, to be jealous of her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No, I assure you, I have no reason to be jealous for her: for to my knowledge, she has irrecoverably disposed of her heart in another place.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What's that? What says she? She's certainly jealous for her self then. there must be something in this.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: In what confusion am I? This can never end well▪ What! I see you are troubled that I have told you a Secret of my Sisters, and discover'd one of yours. Come, walk and consider on't.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I am surpris'd so, I know not what to do in this exigence—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You stare about like a Hare-finder: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Faith▪ Madam, I expected to have met your Sister here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Say you so? the truth on't is, she desired me to take the trouble off her 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I am sorry, Madam, she thinks it so.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You see, Sir, I am content to suffer for her sake.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You have a mind to try me for your Sister, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No: I assure you, Sir, she's resolved never to make trial of you her self, nor by another.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: What can the meaning of this be?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I will be a little plainer with you; She has dispos'd of her heart to another, without power of revocation.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Why wou'd she not meet me▪ to tell me so her self?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: She thought me fitter for't: besides, perhaps this has given her an opportunity to see one she likes better.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I see, Madam, she has not the same kindness for you, to send you to one she likes so ill.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You do not know, but she may have taken as great a trouble off my hands, and kept me from one I like as ill, as she does you.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: There's nothing but Riddle in Woman, they deceive as much with the Vizards of their mind, as they do with those of their faces—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I discover Sir▪ Formal. We must be private no longer.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: So Bruce, you are a happy man, I fee.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You are a pleasant one, I see▪ you and I must come to a clearing of this business.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Ladies, we ha●… 〈◊〉 to impart to you, but shall be hindered by this Coxcomb, Sir Formal

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We must have some consultations too with you. Sister, we'll catch him in a Trap—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Here's a Trap-door of a Vault, where my Uncle keeps his bottles of Air, which he weighs, of which you'll hear more anon. We'll snap him in that, and then we shall have the place to our selves.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll catch him.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, some affairs have engag'd my noble Friend, Sir Nicholas to borrow himself of you a while; and he has commanded me to pawn my person till he shall redeem it with his own—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Very quaintly express'd. We were just desiring your company.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And we were admiring this Talent of yours, your excellent manner of speaking; and I've engag'd to give you a Subject to shew your parts upon to these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: What ever is within the Sphere of my activity, you must command. I must confess, I have some felicity in speaking.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Dear Sister, give him a subject; you shall hear what Oracles hang on his lips. 'Tis all one what subject he speaks upon, great or little.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: That it is, Madam; we Orators speak alike upon all Subjects— My speeches are all so subtilly design'd, that whatever I speak in praise of any thing, with very little alteration, will serve in praise of the contrary.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let it be upon seeing a Mouse inclosed in a Trap.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: 'Tis all one to me, I am ready to speak upon all occasions.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Stand there, Sir, while we place our selves on each side.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
I kiss your hand, Madam. Now I am inspir'd with Eloquence Hem! hem! Being one day, most noble Auditors, musing in my Study upon the too fleeting condition of poor humane kind, I observed, not far from the Scene of my Meditation, an excellent Machine, call'd a Mouse-trap (which my Man had plac'd there) which had included in it a solitary Mouse, which pensive Prisoner, in vain bewayling its own 〈◊〉▪ and the precipitation of it●…●…oo 〈◊〉 〈◊〉▪ 〈◊〉 〈◊〉
for liberty against the too stubborn opposition of solid Wood, and more obdurate Wyer: at last, the pretty Malefactor having tir'd, alass, its too feeble limbs, till they became languid in fruitless endeavors for its excarceration. The pretty Felon, since it could not break Prison, and its offence being beyond the benefit of the Clergy, could hope for no ●…ail, at last sate still pensively lamenting the severity of its Fate, and the narrowness of its, alass! too withering durance: after I had contemplated a while upon the no little curiosty of the Engine, and the subtilty of its Inventor; I began to reflect upon the inticement which so fatally betray'd the uncautious animal to its sudden ruine, and found it to be the too, alass! specious bait of Cheshire cheese, which seems to be a great delicate to the pallat of this Animal, who in seeking to preserve its life, O misfortune, took the certain means to death; and searching for its livelihood, had sadly encounter'd its own destruction. Even so—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Now let the Trap go—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Even so, I say.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Even so, I say, I have catch'd the Orator—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Help! help! murder!

sp.speaker: Longv▪
sp.p: Let the florid Fool lie there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: He uses as many Tropes and Flourishes about a Mouse-trap, as he would in praise of Alexander.

div.stage: Enter Sir Samuel in Womans habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: This is the subt'lest disguise to make love in that e'r was invented; this has serv'd me upon many intrigues. Well, she shall see, for all the sufferings of this day, to the Tune of Kicking, Beating, Pumping, and Tossing in a Blanket, and all that▪ that nothing shall hinder me in my Love. Shall Sir Samuel be frighted from an Intrigue? No!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Whom have we here.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ladies, I was commanded by my Lady Pleasant to wait on you with choice of good things, which she told me, you wou'd buy.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Since she came from my Lady, we must see what she would sell.

sp.speaker: Sir S●….
sp.p:
I have choice of good Gloves, Amber, Orangery, Genoa, Romane, Frangipand, Neroly, Tuberose, Jessimine, and Marshal; all manner of Tires for the Head, Locks, Tours,
Frowzes, and so forth; all manner of Washes, Almond-water, and Mercury-water for the Complexion; the best Peter and Spanish Paper that ever came over; the best Pomatums of Europe, but one rare, one made of a Lamb's Caul and May dew— Also all manner of Confections of Mercury and Hog●…bones, to preserve present, and to restore lost Beauty. If any out-does me in these businesses, or have better Goods than I, I am the Son of a Tinder-box. O Devil! what did I say? I shall betray my self—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How's this, the Son of a Tinder-box?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Pish! I mean the Daughter of a Tinder-box.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This is the Rascal Sir Samuel in disguise.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: In the first place try a pair of Gloves, Madam, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How shou'd I know you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir Samuel's as true a Lover, as e'n wore a head.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this private discourse?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Pox on her envy; she's always for a Cup of Mischief. I'll put this Note into a Glove, and that will do my business. Slap-dash— as flat as a Flounder. I have no private business— Be pleas'd to try on this Glove, Madam. Do not you know me yet?— I am Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What's this? a Note within it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Keep it to your self.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What Note's that? from Sir Samuel Hearty? Oh Heav'n! this is a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A down-right Bawd, and Bawd to that Rascal.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! pull the Bawd in pieces.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Lay hold on the Bawd, we'll have her Carted. Seize her till Sir Nicholas comes in; we'll have her sent to Bridewel, and soundly whipt there, and then Carted.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: So! this is a fine merry way of proceeding. I'have made nimble work on't. Let me go, I am as honest Woman, and labour in my vocation. Let me go, or as I am an honest man I'll sue you about this busines.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: How's this? a Man▪ nay then I'll try a good kicking, upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hold! hold! What do you mean to beat a Woman? will you make me miscarry? I am with child, and for ought I know, you have kill▪ d that within me,

sp.speaker: Bruce▪
sp.p: You said, as you were an honest man.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: O Dunce that I am! That's a way I have of expressing my self. But I'll make you know I am a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: It is my Fool Sir Samuel; prethee Clarinda, let's put him to Sir Formal, and secure him till my Uncle comes; it will make excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you set him upon the Trap, it will do rarely.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: One word with you. Come this way, Sir Samuel. I cannot tell you how much I am afflicted for your sufferings.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Sha! it's no matter. Come it's well it's no worse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Now Clarinda—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: O murder, murder! Who's here? the Devil?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: So, now we have the Garden to our selves. Let's walk, and consult about our affairs—

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Sir Formal and Sir Samuel in the Vault.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I Can no longer contain my self. This Lady, joyn'd with darkness and opportunity, the Midwife of Vice, as we may so say, has so inflam'd me, that I must farther attempt her chastity: I am confident she must be handsome, and no mean person, by her silken Garments. Madam, as I was saying, since we are unwittingly inclos'd in darkness, which yet cannot be so, since enlighten'd by the Rays of your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: For all your Oratory about this business, I cannot see my hand, it is so dark.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! the bright enlightner of the day, by which all Creatures see, is yet it self depriv'd of vision.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Fox o'this damn'd Rhetorick! what will become of me! I must either discover my self, which I wou'd not for the world, or be sent to Bridewel, and be whipt with a Certiorari; and yet me-thinks I have no need on't, for I have been very plentifully kickt and beaten about this business to day already—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
Let me be reveng'd on this fair▪ Enemy, the prettiest, 〈◊〉, and ●…ving hand I ever had the honour to imprint
my kisses on; she has inflam'd me mightily: I'll try her this way. Do me the honour to accept of this Purse, and the contents thereof.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I'll take the Rogues Purse, what e'r come on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, let's make our condition as happy as in us lies.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir! O Lord, Sir, what doye mean? fie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Let me approach the honour of your lip, far sweeter than the Phoenix Nest, and all the spicy Treasures of Arabia.

sp.speaker: Sir Sum.
sp.p: 'Tis your goodness, Sir; but pray forbear—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Nay strive not, upon my sincerity I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, be not uncivil, I am no such person. Nay pish! I never saw the like; you are the strange●…t man. Well, take it then. I vow you make me blush If I were not in apparent danger of being whipt damnably, as missing my masquerade, I cou'd be merry with this Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: The sweets of Hybla dwell upon thy lips! Not all the fragrant bosome of the Spring affords such ravishing perfumes.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir! you are pleas'd to complement! Ah, lying Rogue, my breath smells of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Our time may be but short, pardon the unbecoming roughness which my passion prompts me to. Come, my dear Cloris.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Lord, what a pretty name is that! I was ne'r call'd Cloris before.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Come, my dear Nimph, let us be more familiar: the solitary darkness of the place invites us to Love's silent pleasures. Now, dearest Cloris, let us tast those sweets—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Nay pish! fie! Lord! what do you mean? what wou'd you be at? Keep off. I protest I'll call out. Nay pish! never stir I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Thou hast provok'd my gentle spirit so, it is become furious, and it is decreed I must enjoy thy lovely body—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Out upon you! my body, I de●…e you▪ I am an honest woman. I scorn your words. I will call-out for some body to protect my honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Your Honnor 〈◊〉 suffer; none can see us▪ and: who will declare it?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Out upon you! get you gone, you Swine. I will not suffer in my honor, I am virtuous. Help! help! a Rape! a Rape! help! help.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Be not obstreperous, none can hear you. You have provok'd me contrary to my gentle temper, even to a Rape, Come, I will, I must, i'faith I must.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! the Rogue begins to pry into the difference of Sexes, and will discover mine— I must try my strength with him. Out lustful Tarquin! you libidinous Goat, have at you.

div.stage: Sir Sam. beats Sir Form. kicks him and flings him down.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Help! help! murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Be not obstreperous, none can hear you.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my verity I think this be an Amazon! Well, I can bear this; but—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Do you again attempt my Honour? I'll maul you, you lascivious Villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Hold! hold! I beseech you; I humbly rest contented, I acquiesce.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Get you from me, lustful Swine— Be gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I go, Madam: But I know not whether this Vault doth terminate here, or whether it doth issue farther.

div.head: SCENE, a Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Come, now we are safe in this hold, none will interrupt us in our great design. Ah pox o'these wicked Hectors, vicious impudent Rogues! a Man cannot retire with a Lady for his private satisfaction, but these ranting Rogues must roar and interrupt us; 'tis a very impudent vicious Age in sadness.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: But my Dear, if any body else should have a Key to this Room (as I know they have) thongh I dare not tell him, it is a common Scene of Love matters.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p:
Fear not, the Land-lady tells me, no body has a Key but my self. I have agreed to give her a Guinney a week for these private occasions. In sadness 'tis a fine place: Here a man may bring a Lady, and even none of the house observe it. There is not such a convenience in all the Pall-mall for these occasions, though some there are, much given to such diversions.
How glad am I to have thee here, poor Pigsnie—

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Ah Lord! there's some body at the door—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness there is. There's one with a Key too. In into the Wood-hole quickly, or we shall be discover'd— quick, quick—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come, my Dear Lady, now we are safe from interption; how happy am I in your favours?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Ah! so you say; but if ever I hear of your inconstancy, you shall be no longer happy, as you call it: I cannot suffer a Rival.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Nothing shall e'r divert me from the happiness I enjoy in you; nor am I less impatient of a Rival than you are. I am so covetous of you, that the thought of your Husband keeps me still inquiet.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Fear not a Husband. Husbands are such phlegmatick indifferent Rivals, they ne'r can hurt the Gallants; they poor easie Souls, do every thing as if they did it not.

lg.l: They do but court and keep a pother,
To make one Gamesome for another.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Nay, I think a Husband is very insipid foolish Animal. and is growing out of fashion.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: We shall begin to lay 'em by. Husbands will be left off, as Gentlemen Ushers are: indeed they are more unnecessary Instruments, than those formal spindle-shankt finical Fools, with Nose-gays and white Gloves were.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Those, though they cou'd do no service themselves, wou'd make way for them that cou'd; but a Husband is a Clog, a Dog in a Manger, a Miser, that hords up Gold from others, and will not make use on't himself—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Nay, a thousand times worse; a Miser wou'd keep to himself what he loves, and a Husband what he does not care for. Out on him. A Husband's an Insect, a Drone, a Dormouse—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: A foolish Matrimonial Lump—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A Cuckoo in Winter—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: An Opiat for Love—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A Body without a Soul—

sp.speaker: Haz,
sp.p: A Chip in Porredge.—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A White of an Egg—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: All Flegm, and no Choller—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A Drudge—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: An excuse—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A necessary thing—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: A Cloak at a pinch—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A pitiful Utensil—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Good for nothing, but to cover shame, pay Debts, and own Children for his Wife.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: In short, a Husband is a Husband, and there's an end of him; but a Lover is—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Not to be express'd but in action. I'll shew you what a Lover is with a vengeance, Madam. Come on. 'Sdeath! there's a Key in the doot.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Run into the Wood-hole quickly; I'll bear the brunt, and I may perhaps make a discovery into the bargain—

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas and Mrs. Flirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Come, Dearest, the Land-lady is not at home, or we wou'd have a Collation here.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: O Heav'n! who's this, Hazard?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir! How dare you invade my room?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Oh! who's here? the Devil, the Devil—
Oh Heav'n! who's this? my Husband with a Whore!

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Death and Hell! my Wife with a Hectorly Fellow here! Oh my disgrace.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Oh vile false Man! thy falshood I have long suspected; now this happy opportunity has discover'd all.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What means her impudence?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Was I not sufficient for thee, vile Man, but thou must thus betray me? I cannot look on thee with patience. I shall faint! I shall faint! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Help, help the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Hang the Lady. Oh Woman-kind! what artifice is this? I was inform'd by this Lady I shou'd find you here; I wonder not at your disorder upon this unexpected surprise. O vile treacherous Woman!

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Take him from my sight, I shall die else. Have I been always your obedient, vertuous Wife, and am I thus requited? Heav'n sent this honourable Gentleman to assist me in the discovery, who on purpose got a Key to this Room, it seems the filthy Scene of all thy lust and baseness. Be gone— thou infamous Wretch, I am not able to support the sight of thee—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Lewd Woman! thou abstract of impudence and falshood! tremble at my revenge. Have I at length found out your base lascivious haunt.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O insufferable! do you add to all your barbarous injuries this of aspersing my innocence?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: False man? did I for this give my affection jto thee? and can'st thou think I'll bear this unreveng'd?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! this Wench will undo me with my Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: What do I hear? is he false too? then my misfortunes are compleat. Base vile ungrateful Fellow; is this your constancy and gratitude to me?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Madam, this is a Lady of a great Estate, whom I shou'd have marri'd; and this accident, I fear, has ruin'd all my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Has my kindness deserv'd this? is this your Gallant too? Oh this Villain has made me doubly a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Do not mistake me; this Fellow took me for a great Fortune, and shou'd have marri▪ d me.
Are you consulting for my ruine?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: This is a flam, I'll not believe it▪ This Strumpet has doubly betray'd me. Lewd Creature, first I'll take revenge on thee.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: I thought I should at last find out the cause of my misfortune.
You are like to make a good Husband, that can make so ill a Lover.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: After I have heard all your accusation, which is false, let me tell you, I have been informed of your frequent coming hither with Sir Nicholas, and was resolv'd at once to be reveng'd of him and you, by bringing my Lady hither to discover both.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: O insolence! I never saw the place before.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: ●… am too well satisfied of her falshood, and though it be something below a Philosopher to draw a Sword, yet to punish her I will.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, first you must try with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What are you, her Stallion, and her Bravo too?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Was ever Woman yet so miserable, to be betray'd, by one whom she has lov'd so much better than her life? she wou'd have laid it down to have done him any kindness: and yet to perfect all his cruelty, he blots my reputation. And since the only▪ Treasure of my life is gone, pray make that too. Do not resist him; let him pierce this breast, that ne'r bore any Image but his own. Come on then, cruel man.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake do not betray me to him; if I be not clear'd in this I am undone.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Now hear me Sir: This Lady, on my honour, Sir, is free from all blemish, I believe even in thought. But I being inform'd you use to come with that Lady to this House, of ill reputation, in anger to you both betray'd you to my Lady: I dogg'd her Messenger from her Lodging to you, and immediately gave notice to my Lady; and in all hast we came—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Indeed I have been acquainted with this Lady, being a Virtuosa, upon Philosophical matters, but never saw her here, till we now came for this discovery. She inform'd me, she saw you two come hither, and my Wife being gone out before me, and alone, gave me more suspicion.

sp.speaker: Fliat.
sp.p: I having seen you privately talking with my Lady in the Mall, suspected you; and to revenge my self on her and you, I sent for him, and we have dogg'd you hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: But why was she hidden to avoid my sight, if she came for a discovery?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: She thought to have discover'd more by being unseen, and over-hearing your discourse.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Now see, injurious man, how you have wrong'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Though I hope I have deceiv'd her with a lie, yet what she says looks like truth.
It must be so. Come, no more; I will believe you true, and so am I.

sp.speaker: Flirt.
sp.p: Though this sham passes upon him, I know too well you are guilty, good Mr. Hazard, and I hate you for't.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Prethee hold thy peace, I am kept by her, as I know ou are by him— I am kept, I—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Heav'n knows I am true.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: And Heav'n can witness for my innocence.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I am glad that all things are thus happily clear'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: But what was it frighted you within, my Dear?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: There is some body in the Wood-hole.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Now all's over, I'll see who it is. Come out here. What's here? a Woman—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: A shame on her; how sneakingly she looks? This is some Strumpet I warrant you. Oh! Foh! how I hate such Cattle! Heav'n grant she did not hear me and Hazard.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Here's a Man too. Come out of your hole. Mr. Snarl is it you?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Is this the fruit of your virtue, and declaiming against the vice of the Age?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Heav'n! if he over-heard me, I am ruin'd eternally. I'll try him. We met all here upon a mistake, which is now happily rectifi'd. But 'tis too apparent, Uncle, you came for wickedness and abomination.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: I scorn your words, Madam, I am civil and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ay in sadness are we; our intentions were honourable. I meet this Lady upon a virtuous account, by the Mass. I love and honour her in a civil way, and scorn your filthy lascivious Beasts of this Age.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Remember, Sir, I have you on the hip; no more will I endure your frumps and taunts about my Philosophy, and the noble exercise of my parts.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Nephew, let me tell you, you are an Ass in sadness, and Iwill make you know this Lady is virtuous, yes, as virtuous as your Ladiship; and I will defend her honour with my Sword by the Mass; and he that dares be so presumptous to contradict it, let him draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Gad forgive me, what means he?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No, none are so much concern'd at it— But what are these Rods which I drew out with you? what do they mean?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: O Devil— I shall be betray'd. Ha! Rods! what a pox know I what they are? I believe the Mistris of the House is a School-Mistris.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Yes, she keeps a very virtuous School, for the disciplining of hopeful towardly old Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: ●…ig.
sp.p: Now my honour's clear. Let's go, Sir. Besides, h●…res that base Creature Flirt; I cannot abide the sight of her, since she discommended thee, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Come, Madam— In sadness this is very fine. Two civil persons cannot meet privately in an affectionate way, but such as you must censure them. But I will make you know this Lady is honourable; I will, in sadness, and so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Come, my Dear, now let's go home: do not grieve at my unhappy jealousie, since my belief of thy dear Truth is more confirm'd by it— Come, my Dear—

div.stage: Enter Longvil, Bruce, Miranda, and Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, to divert this insipid talk of Love, a Theme so thred-bare, no man can speak new sense upon it: My Maid shall sing you a new Song she learnt the other day.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You must expect much Wit in it: for Poets are grown such good Husbands, they'll lay out none upon a Song.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: All we must look for, is smooth Verse, and a good Tune.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And how a good Tune, and tinckling Rhime attones for nonsense, the Songsters and Heroicks of the time may sufficiently convince you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: They make nonsence go down as glib without tasting, as a seditious Lie is swallow'd in a City Coffee house, or Common-wealth Club, without examination.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But now let's hear it—

lg.l: HOw wretched is the Slave to Love,
Who can no real pleasures prove;
For still they're mixt with pain●…:
When not obtain'd, restless is the desire.
Enjoyment puts out all the fire,
And shows the Love was vain.
I●… wanders to another soon,
Wanes and Encreases like the Moon,
And like her never rests:
〈◊〉 Tides of Pleasure now, and then of Tears;
Makes Ebbs and Flows of Joys and Cares.
〈◊〉 lovers wavering breasts.
but 〈◊〉 of Love I will be free,
And triumph in the liberty:
I wi●…hout him enjoy.
〈◊〉▪ worst of Prisons I'll my Body bind,
Rather than Chain my free-born mind.
For such a foolish Toy.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: But to us there is no Musick like Love, or Harmony like the consent of Lover's hearts.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But as Musick is improv'd by practise, Love decays by it, and therefore I scarce dare talk on't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let what harmony soever be between Lovers at first, in a short time it turns to scurvy jangling; and therefore can you blame us if we divert so dangerous a thing any way—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I confess it may come to discord, but 'tis as in Musick▪ if it be made good, it makes the following concord better.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: If they play upon one another, till they are out of Tune, they must needs jangle.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: In that case they must lay by, and tune again, and then strike up afresh.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: That Simile, will never hold; for when Love grows once out of Tune, they may scew and keep a coil▪ but 'twill never stand in Tune again.

sp.speaker: Clrr.
sp.p: 'Tis most certain: when Love comes once to bend, it breaks presently.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: But perhaps it may be set again like a broken Limb, and be the stronger for't.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No: when Love breaks, 'tis into so many splinters, 'tis never to be set again.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Shift for your selves, Sir Nichol●… and my 〈◊〉 are both return'd home again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O mischievous ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Unlucky accident.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I must look after Sir Formal.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Their carriage, since their cross appointment in the Garden, has too evidently declar'd their intentions. We have mistaken, I see, if we deign to 〈◊〉, we must change Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p:
'Tis too evident, we have plac'd our Loves wrong,
They are handsome, rich, and honest, three qualities that seldome meet in Women.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and since 'twill be necessary, after all our Rambles, to fix our unsetled lives, to be grave, formal, very wise, and serve our Countrey, and propagate our species; Let us think on't here.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let us walk and consult about this weighty affair.

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas, Lady Gimcrack, Clarinda, Miranda.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: A Woman with a Letter, a Tire-Woman too! are they all Bawds? Their very Art of washing and adorning Women in implicite Bawding, but this is down-right explicite Bawdery.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Good Sir, let her be made an Example to all vile Women.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: We have secur'd her in the Vault here.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: You have done well, she shall be brought to condign punishment.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But we can tell you yet a stranger thing; Sir Formal is privately shut up with this lewd Woman, and has been this hour.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Tis very true; what his intentions are, I know not, but▪ tis a very scandalous thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O Monstrum horrendum! Is my Friend, that seeming vertuous man, faln into the snare?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O Virtue, whither art thou fled? my House is dishonoured, abus'd! I am ready to faint when I hear of lewdness. My Dear, do not endure it; I shall never endure my House again; let it with all speed, and let's remove.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Prethee, Dear; be pacifi'd.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Oh I cannot be pacifi'd: my brood rises when I hear of lewd whoring Fellows; I wou'd have 'em all hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Excellent Hypocrite!

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Well, Heav'n be prais'd, I am the happiest Man in a Wife. I will rebuke him: but for the Baw●…, I'll have a Warrant from the next Justice; I will have her Whipt and Carted. Come, bring 'em out here.
sp.stage: [Servants bring in Sir Formal and Sir Samuel▪
sp.p: Truly Sir Formal, I am much asham'd, to find a 〈◊〉 in such a posture with a lewd woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Why, Sir, upon my sincerity.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Out upon you, have you the face to speak in your own defence, or in defence of this odious Vice? Out on't! you think to bring all off with your Eloquence; but I'll not hear it: You have defiled my house, and committed lewdness within the walls.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Why, Ladies, you know—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What, you are angry we have discover'd you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Would you have had us keep your pernicious counsel? had that been becoming our virtue?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Why, Sir Nicholas, I profess—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I cannot suffer it. 'Tfit such Hypocrites should be punish'd. Is this your Virtue? your sereneness of mind? and are all your Flowers of Rhetorick come to this?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I know not what to say in your excuse, to retire with such a lewd Creature. I did not think you cou'd have faln into so shameful a scandal. I am sorry, since 'twill be a reproach to all Virtuoso's.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: By my Integrity.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: You are a man of integrity, to meet privately with a filthy Creature, a Bawd! an ugly Bawd too!

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I scorn your words; neither a Bawd, nor ugly, neither by your leave— Ugly, and Bawd, quoth she?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Can I not be heard? shall Oratory have no place?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: You think to bewitch us with your Oratory, but 'tis too apparent; you have dishonour'd my house.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Here are some Phaenomena's of scandal, but I will dissolve all in a punctum of time.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I will never endure you, you shall solve none of your Phaenomena's here more.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I confess I was found here (privately with this Woman, but no less true—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Pray let me hear him speak—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: My Oratory was never slighted before; when did I open my mouth in vain before? I confess—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why look you, Sir, he confesses it; what wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Will you not believe us, he has been privately with her this hour?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I say, Peace; I will hear him.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I confess to you all—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: D'you see again? ●…e confesses to us all—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Now my shame comes upon me.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What! is my florid Fool catch'd with a Whore? an ugly Whore? does your noble Soul operate clearly without the clog of your sor did humane Body now? you are a fine formal Hypocrite, in sadness; by the Mass it's a fine world we live in.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I am confident my Friend is innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: He innocent? hang him, he wou'd have ravish'd me, if I had not been stronger than he, and beaten him soundly: my Honour had suffer'd upon that business—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: O Tempora! O Mores! but I doubt not but I shall shine clearer after this Eclipse; I will bear these wrongs with a serene temper of mind.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Hang you! never trust your Orator, in sadness they will all lie like Dogs: by the Mass I would go fifty miles to see an Orator hang'd. Orators are Rogues, the very grievances of the Nation, always putting in an Oar, and prating and disturbing the business of the Nation, with their foolish Tropes, and care not which way matters go so they may shew their parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I do believe you, Sir Formal. You young Sluts; will you never leave?

sp.speaker: ●…ir.
sp.p: Will you not take the Womans word?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What a Bawd's word! she suffer in her honour one that brought a Letter to you—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A Bawd! I scorn your words; I brought a Letter from a Gentleman that makes honorable Love, and wou'd marry her.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: A Match-maker! that's worst of all.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Your Marriage▪ Bawd, your Canonical-Bawd is worst of all; they betray people for their lives-time. Here, carry her, and lock her up in the green-room; I'll maul your Bawdship.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! I shall be whipt, nay, which is ten times worse, I shall disappoint the Town, and have no Masquerade to ●…ight. But I'll bayl my self with Money, if it be possible—

sp.speaker: ●…ir.
sp.p: Courage! my Sist●…●…ought this upon you but I'll redeem all.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Nay, if I succeed in my love, I care not if I be beaten, kickt, and whipt, as if Heav'n and Earth wou'd come together.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Come, I'll see her lockt up safe my self; filthy Creature!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Not a word more o'this business. I could not forbear the trick; but you will find me more favourably▪

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I shall be content to suffer any thing for your swee●… sake.—

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: If you had come sooner, you might ha'taken this Orator, this flashy Fellow, with a Whore, in sadness, a foul deformed Strumpet—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my honour, Gentlemen, I am wrong'd; but he was taken with a Lady, and Rods too, in German-street, about an hour since.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: What, this virtuous Gentleman of the last Age?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: One that so justly reproaches the Vices of this? It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Oh Dog! Rogue! Nephew, I'll be reveng'd. No, it cannot be, it is not. The Orator's a Son of a Whore, and my Nephew a foolish Rascally Philosopher, one good for nothing but an empty noise of florid words, without sense, in ●…adness. And the other good for nothing but useless Experiments upon Flies▪ Maggots, Eels in Vinegar, and the Blue upon Plumbs, which he finds to be living Creatures: but all the world will find him an Ass, and so I leave him and all of yee, with a pox t'yee. But in sadness, Orator, I will beat thee mightily. I with a Whore? I scorn your words by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I know he's in a rage, but 'tis true; Sir Formal, we'll no more endure his taunts. But now he talks of Eels, I'll shew you millions in a Sawcer of Vinegar; they resemble other Eels, save in their motion, which in others is side-ways, but in them upwards and downwards, thus, and very slow.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: We have heard of these, Sir, often.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Another difference is, these have sharp stings in their nails. By the way, the sharpest Vinegar is most full of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Then certainly the sharpness, or biting of Vinegar, proceeds from those stings, striking upon the Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I see you are a most admirable observer: it must needs be so. So, this is a rare Phaenomenon solv'd by the by.

I have often concluded that before— The whole Air is full of living Creatures, a thousand times less visible than those living Creatures, mistaken for Motes in the Sun; I know most of 'em distinctly by my Glasses.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: ilk of use. These are the Mysteries of Natures Closet.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This foolish Virtuoso does not consider, that one Brick-layer is worth forty Philosophers.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Then for the Blue upon Plumbs, it is nothing but many living Creatures. I have observ'd upon a Wall-plum (with my most exquisite Glasses, which cost me several thousands of pounds) at first beginning to turn blue, it comes first to Fluidity, then to Orbiculation, then Fixation, so to Angulization, then Christallization, from thence to Germination or Ebullition, then Vegetation, then Plantan●…nimation, perfect Animation, Sensation, Local Motion, and the like—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there are a great number of sick men waiting in the Hall for your Worship, and desire to be dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen you shall see my method of practise. Sir Formal, will you go and rank 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Form
sp.p: I obey in my wonted Office. Gentlemen, I humbly kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: He ranks the 〈◊〉 people in their several Classes, Formes, or Orders of Diseases. To save trouble, you shall see all.

sp.speaker: Serv
sp.p: Sir, the Constable is come with a Warrant to carry the Bawd away.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Come, we will deliver the Bawd into their Clutches, and when I have administred to my sick, we'll take the air▪ By the way, Gentlemen, what Countrey air do you like best?

sp.speaker: Bru●…c.
sp.p: thy we cannot travel far for't this evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Travel! I thought I should have you. Why I never travel, I take it in a close chamber.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Why you can take but one kind of nasty smoaky air in a Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Th●…re's your Mistake. Chuse your Air, you shall have it in my Chamber; Newmarket, Banstead-down, Wiltshire, Bury-air, Norwich-air; what you will.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Would a man think it possible for a Virtuoso to arrive at this extravagance?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you; it is beyond the wit of man to invent such extravagant things for them, as their folly finds out for themselves. Is it possible to take all these several Countrey Airs in your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I knew you were to seek. I employ men all over England, Factors for Air, who bottle up Air, and weigh it in all places, sealing the Bottles Hermetically: they send me Loads from all places. That Vault is full of Countrey-air.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: To weigh Air, and send it to you!

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O yes, I have sent one to weigh Air at the Picque of T●…nerifs, that's the lightest Air. I shall have a considerable Cargo of that Air. Sheerness and the Isle of Dogs Air is the heaviest. Now if I have a mind to take Countrey Air, I send for, may be, forty Gallons of Bury Air, shut all my windows and doors close, and let it fly in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This is a most admirable invention.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But to what purpose do you weigh Air?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: That I shall tell you as we are taking it. Now let's see this Bawd dispos'd of: every thing in its order.

div.stage: Sir Samuel in the Chamber solus.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p:
How long shall I expect my fate? Well! there never was such a Martyr in Love, to be kickt, beaten, pump'd; toss'd in a blanket about bus'ness, and now in danger of being whipt with a slap-dash. But she loves me! come, 'tis well 'tis no worse! but to miss my Masquerade, that's the sum of all: but I'll bribe my Justice and escape. 'Tis a Trade; some of the Justices are liker Malefactors than Magistrates: but 'twill cost me a plaguy deal, for this damn'd Vertuoso▪ will prosecute furiously. Ha! what's here, a Rope? I am deliver'd as Rabby Busie was by Miracle. I'll slide down from the window into the garden▪ The back-door's open: so I save my money ipso facto, and go to my Ball; and, Whip stich, your 〈◊〉 in my Breech, Sir Nicholas. I'll leave my Cloaths behind
me. Though I am Bawd above, I am Sir Samuel underneath. So Tyre-woman, lie thou there, and away Knight. 'Tis well 'tis no worse—

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas, Longv. Bruce, L. G. Clar. Mir. Servants, Constables, Officers.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Come! where is this Bawd? now we shall make her an example. Here! where are you? Ha! here's no body.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I am sure I saw her lockt in.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The door was lockt when we came in: here are her Cloaths too.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: The Rogue has stript himself, and has escap'd naked.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: O Heav'n! this must be the Devil: the House is haunted.

sp.speaker: Sir For●….
sp.p: I have set all the sick men in order, and they wait for your prescription.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O Sir Formal, your Mistriss is flown, and has left her case behind her▪

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: The doors are fast, and she is flown out of the Chimney: have a care, Sir Formal, if you were naught with her, you will be torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Not I upon my sincerity.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: It was undoubtedly a Spirit. I could have told you that before, but I was afraid I shou'd fright you all.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: How, Sir! was it a Spirit say you?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: You must know, Sir, I am much skilled in Rosacrucian Learning. I am one of the Vere adepti, as simple as I stand here. I discover'd it by my sight, having familiar Conversation with Spirits.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O the subtilty of this Vertuoso. This notable Spirit Sir Sa●…el makes a ball to night; we will steal out one way or other.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You'll remember the Masquerade Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, yes! we will see the Spirit.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I see your cross Love, and will plague ye, ye young Sluts, for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: You converse with a great many people which you take to be men and women▪ but we Rosa-crucians know 'em to be spirits. Now let us go to my sick people, and administer.

div.head: SCENE, is the Court-yard full of several Lame and Sick people.
div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas, Sir Formal, Longvil, and Bruce.

sp.speaker: Sick peo.
sp.p: Heav'n bless your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, you must know I have studi'd all manner of Cases, and have Bills ready written for all Diseases; that's my way, I give 'em advice for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Not more resorted to the Temple of Aesculapius; I am sure not so many found relief, as from my Noble Friend: You have reason, good languishing people, to be Trumpeters to his Illustrious Fame, whose indefatigable care, for the good of feeble and distress'd Mankind, with his transcendent skill, each day cures even incurable diseases.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Your Orators are very subject to that Figure in Speech, call'd a Bull.

sp.speaker: Sir. Nic.
sp.p: I still administer'd to the incurable in Italy, and never fail'd of success. Here are my Bills. Where is the Roll? call it over.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Gout.

sp.speaker: 2 Gout.
sp.p: Here—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: There's a Bill for you two, take it betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Stone.

sp.speaker: 2 Stone.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: There's one for you two.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Scurvy.

sp.speaker: 4 Scurv.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: There's a Bill for you four.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Go, pass by as you are serv'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Consumption.

sp.speaker: 2 Consum.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Take your Bill.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Dropsie.

sp.speaker: 2 Drops.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: There's for you two.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: There is a Mad-man I have set by for transfusion of blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: That's well. The truth on't is, we shall never get any but Mad-men, for that Operation. But proceed.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: These are the last, but not the least.
Pox.

div.stage: Enter a great number of Men and Women.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here, here, here—

sp.speaker: Sir. Nich.
sp.p: There are three or four Bills for you, you are so many.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heav'n bless your Worship—

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Sir. Form.
sp.p: HOw long shall I languish in expectation of your noble favour, for the enjoyment of whic h, my desires are as great, as my deserts are little?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Truly, Sir Formal, I am so sensible of your service, and so troubled with my confinement under my Uncle, that at length I have determin'd by you, to free my self from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, I am too suddenly blest, I am all Rapture, all Extasie, my Soul, methinks, is fled from its corporeal clog, and I am all unbodi'd, Divinest Lady. Let me kneel and adore that hand, that snowy hand, to which the Snow it self is tann'd and Sun-burnt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Not too mnch of this: but in short, conduct my Sisters and me out of these doors to the Masquerade; for we canno' get out without your authority with the Porter, and after you have return'd to my Uncle sometime; procure the habit of Scaramoncha, that I may know you, and come to us, and you shall absolutely dispose of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Madam, I'll flie; nay, out-fly Sir Nicholas himself, to do you service, or any Vertuoso in England▪ But how shall I know you? you'll be disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Clar▪
sp.p: ●… ll find you out; besides, you know this Ring and Bracelet. We must have our Maids with us, for we ll not return. Let's find my sister, and about it instantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I am all obedience. I should not envy now an Universal Monarch— I hear my Ladies voyce—

div.stage: Enter▪ Sir Nicholas, Longvil, and Servant to Sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Bruce is coming to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sir. Nic.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant. Now open the Bottles, and let the Air flie, Gentlemen, be ready to snuff it up. O this Bur●…Air is delicate, 'tis delicious; O very refreshing.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: O admirable— who would go to Bury to take it?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Not I, 'tis much the better here; it takes so much the fresher for being botled, as other Liquors do. For let me tell you, Gentlemen, Air is but a thinner sort of Liquor, and drinks much the better for being botled.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Most certainly the world is very foolish, not to snuff up botled Air, as they drink botled Drink.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: The foolish World is never to be mended. For all this, your Glass-Coach will to Hide-park for Air. The Suburb-fools trudge to Lambs-Conduit or Totnam; your sprucer sort of Citizens gallop to Epsom; your Mechanick gross Fellows, shewing much conjugal affection, strut before their Wives, each with a Child in his Arms, to Islington, or Hogsdon.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Ay poor dull Fools!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: But to what end do you weigh this Air, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: To what end shou'd I? to know what it weighs. O knowledge is a fine thing; why I can tell to a Grain what a gallon of any Air in England weighs.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Is that all the use you make of these Pneumatick Engines?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: No, I eclipse the light of rotten Wood, stinking Whitings and Thornback, and putrid Flesh when it becomes lucid.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Will stinking Flesh give light like rotten Wood?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O yes; there was a lucid Surloin of Beef in the Strand, foolish people thought it burnt, when it onely became lucid and chrystalline by the coagulation of the aqueous juice of the Beef, by the corruption that invaded it. 'Tis frequent. I my self have read a Geneva Bible by a Leg of Pork.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: How, a Geneva Bible by a Leg of Pork?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O Ay, 'tis the finest Light in the World: but for all that, I could eclipse the Leg of Pork in my Receiver, by pumping out the Air; but immediately upon the appulse of the Air let in again, it becomes lucid as before.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Is it so curious a Light?

sp.speaker: Sin Nic.
sp.p:
O admirable! I am now studying of Glow-worms, a
fine Study; it is a curious Animal: I think I shall preserve 'em light all the year, and then I'll never use any other light in my Study but Glow-worms and Concave-glasses.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: What do you with the Speaking-Trumpet?

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: O that Stentrophonical Tube, though not invented by me, yet is improv'd beyond all mens expectations.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: They can hear distinctly a League at Sea by them already.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Pi●…! that's nothing; I have made one, you may hear eight mile about, and I shall improve it very much more: for 〈◊〉 no stop in Art. But of all Languages, none is heard so far as Greek; your Ionick Dialect of O●…o does so roul in the found. I make Sir Formal speak Greek often in it.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: This Sir Formal was a great many pretty Employments under him.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I doubt not but in three moneths to improve it so, that from the chief Mountain, Hill, or Eminence in a County, a man may be heard round the County.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This will be above all wonder.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I have thought of this to do the King service; for when I have perfected it, there needs but one Pardon to Preach to a whole County; the King may then take all the Church-Lands into his own hands, and serve all England with his Chaplains in Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This is a most admirable project. But what will become of the rest of the Parsons?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: It is no matter, let 'em learn to make Wollen Cloth, and advance the Manufacture of the Nation; or learn to make Nets, and improve the Fishing-Trade; it is a fine sedentary life for those idle Fellows in black.

sp.speaker: Bruce
sp.p: These illiterate Virtuoso's hate all that have relation to Learning.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You cannot blame 'em. But there being no stop in Art, you may advance this Trumpet so far, you may make 'em talk from one Nation to another.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic
sp.p: So I may in time.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
