sp.p: By this Princes may converse, treat, congratulate, and condole, without the great charge and trouble of Ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p:
I hope to effect it▪ But I wonder Sir Formal is not
return'd; I sent his to fix my Tellescopes for surveying the Moon.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Do you believe the Moon is an Earth, as you told us?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Believe it! I know it; I shall shortly publish a Book of Geography for it. Why, 'tis as big as our Earth; I can see all the Mountainous parts▪ and Vallies and Seas, and Lakes in it; nay, the larger sort of Animals, as Elephants and Camels; but publick Buildings and Ships very easily. I have seen several Battels fought there. They have great Guns, and have the use of 〈◊〉. At Land they fight with Elephants and Castles. I have seen 'em—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: No Phanatick that has lost his Wits in Revelation, is so mad as this Fool.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You are mistaken, this is but a faint Copy to some Originals among the Tribe.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: There's now a great Monarch, who has Armies in several Countreys in the Moon, which we find out, because the Colours which we see are all alike. There are a great many States, which we take to be Confederates against him. He is a very ambitious Prince▪ and aims at Universal Monarchy; but the rest of the Moon will be too hard for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I have fix'd the Tubes in the Garden; and, if we be not deceived, the great Monarch is making an Attaque upon a Town, and they are in very hard Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis probable— We'll haste to see it. But first do me the favour to speak two or three Greek Verses in this Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.stage: [Sir Formal speaks some Verses out of Homer.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir! stand upon your Guard; the House is beset by a great Rabble of People, who threaten to pull you out of it, and tear you in pieces.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O Heav'n! what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, they are Ribbon-weavers; who have been informed, that you are he that invented the Engine-Loom, which has provok'd 'em to rise up in Arms, and they are resolv'd to be reveng'd for't: Listen, Sir, you may hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir. Nic.
sp.p:
O what will become of me! Gentlemen, Gentlemen,
for Heav'ns sake do something for me; I protest and vow they wrong me, I never invented any thing of use in my life, as gad shall mend me not I.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We shall be beaten for being in such damn'd company, and faith we shall deserve it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Mercy on me! how loud they are!
O Gentlemen, What is to be done?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Get your Guns and Pistols charg'd. The Rabble, like wild Beasts, are frighted at Fire-arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Go, get 'em charg'd quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Now is the time for me to shew my parts. I have another Weapon. Let me alone with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What Weapon, Sir Formal?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Eloquence: I warrant ye. Let me alone. I'll go out among 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O 'twill never do; they are very outrageous Rogues. What will become of us?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: You know not the charmes of Oratory.

'Twas my fortune to be near the Temple▪ stairs, when the Watermen, who had drunk too deep of a Liquor, somewhat stronger than that which is the Scene of their Vocation, were stirr'd up into so popular a heat and fervour, that its fury threatned the adjacent Society— The Water-men were themselves (as I may so say) blown into a Tempest, when strait I ventur'd in among the intemperate Crowd, and by the force of Rhetorick, dispell'd the barbarity of their over-boyling Ale, and too much fermented Choller, and gently recompos'd their minds into a sedate and quiet temper: and I doubt not but to have the same effect upon these.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: Quickly then, dispatch. Tell 'em I am innocent, I never invented any thing in my life. Go-go, quickly.

div.head: The SCENE the Street, a great Rabble of People together, and Snarl, &c.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What ever they say, this Sir Nicholas, and one Sir Formal that's with him, invented the Engine-loom, to the confusion of Ribbon-weavers. I shall be sufficiently reveng'd on the Rogues now.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: O Villains! we'll maul 'em. Are these the tricks of a Vertoso? have they studi'd these fourteen years for this?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Yes, for much less. The truth is, 'tis a burning shame that poor men should be ruin'd by such Fellows, in sadness 'tis—

sp.speaker: 2. Weav.
sp.p: I never thought these Vertoso's wou'd do any thing but mischief, for my part.

sp.speaker: 3. Weav.
sp.p: Where are the Rogues? Come out of your Den.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Come out! where are the Vertoso's here?

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Break open the house. Open the doo,, or we'll demolish—

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: What wou'd you have? stand off?

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: What wou'd you have, you Son of a Whore; the Engine, and the Rogues that invented it.

sp.speaker: Porter within.
sp.p: Here's no Engine, no Rogues, nor Inventers neither—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Now will I try my Eloquence. Come, Gentlemen, What is it you wou'd have? What is the fountain of your discontents? now for the power of Oratory! Come, come, come—

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Here's one of the Rascals, take him amongst you.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Why, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Weav.
sp.p: Tear him in pieces.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I say, Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: 3. Weav.
sp.p: Cut off his ears.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Take him and hang him upon the next Sign▪

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, hang him up quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Hold! hold! shall I not speak?

sp.speaker: 2. W●…av.
sp.p: Yes, if you can after you are hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Why, Gentlemen, I am of your side. If you commit this rash outrage, you will be soundly punish'd upon a Quare fremuerunt Gentes—

sp.speaker: So●…e.
sp.p: Let him speak.

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.p: No, he shall not speak; hang him—

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Hold, Neighbours and Friends, let's hear him; he●… may perhaps discover something of this business.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Let him speak—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p:
By what occasion or accident this unheard of Torrent of tempestuous-rage was thus inflam'd, ●… very much ignore. But let it not be said that Englishmen, good common-wealth's men, and sober discreet Ribbon-weavers, should be thus hurri'd
by the rapid force of the too dangerous Whirlwind, or Hurricane of passion.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav
sp.p: He speaks notably.

sp.speaker: 2. Weav.
sp.p: He's a well-spoken man truly—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Of passion, I say, which with its sudden and, alas! too violent circumgyrations, does too often shipwrack those that are agitated by it, while it turns them into such giddy confusion, that they can no longer trim the Sails of Reason, or steer by the Compass of Judgment.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: His Tongue's well hung, but I know not what he means by all this stuff.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I say, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Weav.
sp.p: Pox on you, you shall say no more. What's this to the invention of the Loom?

sp.speaker: 3. Weav.
sp.p: This is one of the Inventers, hang him. Where's t'other? break open the house

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas, Bruce, and Longvil above.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Do but hear me?

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: No, Rascal, we will not hear you.

div.stage: [They beat him, kick him, and fling Oranges at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: All this I can bear, if you will but hear me, Gentlemen— I am a person—

sp.speaker: 2. Weav.
sp.p: A person, a Rogue, a Villain! a damn'd Vertoso! A person!

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I say, Gentlemen, I am a person—

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Pox on you— we'll use you like a Dog— Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Quousque tandem efsrenata jactabit audacia.
This is a barbarity which Scythians would blush at.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Scythians! What a pox does he call us names? take him, and hang him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I see Sir Formal's Oratory cannot prevail; What shall I do?

sp.speaker: ●…. Weav.
sp.p: O there he is. Come down, or we'll fetch you down, and your Engine too.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to sally out—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Give us Pistols, quickly—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p:
Hear me, Gentlemen, I never invented an Engine in my life; as gad shall sa' me you do me wrong. I never invented so much as an Engine to pair Cream▪ cheese with. We Vertuoso's
〈◊〉 find out any thing of use, 'tis not our way.

sp.speaker: 1. Weav.
sp.p: Hang your way. You are a damn'd lying Vertoso. Break open the door quickly—

div.stage: Enter Longvil and Bruce below with Pistols, Servants.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Where are these Dogs?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Murder! murder!

div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas creeping out with a Blunderbus.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Where are these Rogues?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Sirra, go and call the Guard, least they should rally again.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Sir Formal is shot, and all the Rabble is escap'd unhurt.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O my Friend! Sir Formal! Sir Formal!

sp.speaker: Sir Formal.
sp.p: I am alive, Sir Nicholas, but surely I am shot.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Let's search— Here is no hole in your cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Hum— I find no blood. Truly I did opine that I was shot— but I am exceedingly beaten and bruised, Though there be no discretion, I have suffered much confusion.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I see your Oratory could not prevail.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: No, no, these Barbarians understand not Eloquence. I must go in, and discover this disorder—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let's take this opportunity to get rid of the Vertuoso, and go to the Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Sir, the Guard was coming to suppress the tumult ere I went; they seiz'd some of the Mutineers, and dispers'd the rest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Now we are safe, Sir. We humbly take our leaves till to morrow—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your humble Servant;
Where are my Wife and Nieces?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: They are gone abroad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic▪
sp.p: At this time o' night? Did they go together?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: No, Sir, my Lady went alone▪

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: And did you let my Nieces go out, Villain, without your Lady?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Sir Formal carried them out.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: ‛ Death! what design is this? they are gone to the Masquerade: My Wife alone too! I like not this▪ The story in German-street was very suspitious. I shall find out these practises.

div.head: The SCENE is a large Room, with a great number of Masqueraders, Men and Women, in many 〈◊〉 habits.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Now, Hazard, let's enjoy our selves: I am never in my Element, but when I am adventuring about an Intriguo, or Masquerading about business. Now you shall see me shew my parts.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Do. Sir Samuel, you are excellent at these things.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Nay, if any man outdoes me about this business. Well, no more to be said. Is not mine a very pretty Disguise? Ha!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: An admirable one—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I have forty of 'em upon Intriguo's and businesses. But now to work. Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No: yet me-thinks you look through your disguise like a foolish Fellow I have seen.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: A foolish Fellow— Hey poop! you were never so much in the wrong in your life, as gad mend me—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I do not think so; a Mask might cover deformity, but not folly. You have the very Meen of a Coxcomb; all the motions of your body declare the weakness of your mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Pish! what you are upon the high Ropes now. Whip st●…ch, Your nose in my breech. Pish! I▪ ll talk no more with her.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: No; I neither know ye, nor care to know ye.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: They who have so little curiosity, have less pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I ghess your inside to be no better than your outside.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Try 'em both, and you'l be of another opinion.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The Conviction's not worth the Trial.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I wonder which is Hazard. But my business is not with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: These are very angry Ladies, Hazard. Just now we met two were very kind to us. Pretty Rogues. They had delicate hands, arms and necks— and they were Women of Quality, I'm sure by their Linnen▪—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: That's no rule— for Whores wear as good Linnen as honest Women: fine Clothes and good Linnen are the Working-Tools of their Trade.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: But I know by their Wit and Repertees they were fine persons. I am confident my Woman knowes me, and has a kindness for me.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Me-thought they seem'd to be rank Strumpets—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Prethee hold thy peace. T●…ce is Latine for a Candle. I am us'd to these Intregues and Businesses—

div.stage: Enter Longvil and Bruce in their own Clothes, Masqued.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Longv. and Brace! let's watch them, and see where they'l direct themselves.

sp.speaker: Mir
sp.p: Like right-bred men o'th'Town; I warrant upon the next they light on.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: 'Ods my life, I ha' lost my Lac'd Handkercher—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: ‛ Death! I had ' lost mine too. Heart! all my money's gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Ha! Money! what a pox, mine's all flown too. Whip, slap-dash—

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Whip, slap-dash! a pox o'your Women of Quality, they are flown too. Whip, slap-dash— But you have been us'd to such Intriguo's and Businesses—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I durst ha'sworn I could not be deceiv'd. Though I ha▪ been often serv'd so by Vizard Masques in the Pit, they are mightily given to't; we men of adventure must bear this▪ Come, no more to be said. Come, 'tis well it's no worse. Come!

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This is a fine civil Assembly truly. The Knight has great conveniences of Coaches and Retiring-Rooms.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: It is a very rank Ball; there's like to be very much Fornication committed to night.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: A Masquerade's good for nothing else, but to hide blushes, and bring bashful people together, who are asham'd to sin bare-fac'd. There's a Lady hovering about you, and longs to pickeer with you.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: O that it were Clarinda in a good mind.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I wish it be not Miranda in a bad one; her shape's like hers—

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Come, Fidles, be ready— Shall I wait on you in a Dance about business—
The Bor●…—
sp.stage: [They Dance, Sir Samuel leaves her, She takes in another.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A Corant.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: May I not have the honour to know who you are▪

sp.speaker: L. Gim▪
sp.p: 'Tis sufficient to tell you, I am one you have no ill wishes to, and would not tell you this but in Masque.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: She's finely shap'd, and by her Jewels a Woman of some condition. Come, off with this Cloud to a good face, and Ornament to a bad one.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: No: but if you will withdraw into another Room, I'll let you know more of my mind, though not of my face.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: The temptation is too strong to be resisted. Let's steal off.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Very fine, I swear very fine—
Where the Devil's this Miranda? I cannot find her out for my life—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Did you not see Bruce steal off with a Lady?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, and cannot bear it. I am so foolish, I wou'd I were not.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: But hold. Who held my Sword while I danced? 'Twas a French Sword, cost me fifteen Pistols: a curse on him, he▪ s rubb'd off with— But Come, 'tis well its no worse yet—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This Bruce stayes somewhat long, I like it not. If I cou'd find out either Clarinda or Miranda here, I shou'd be out of doubt— Let me see, who are you?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: What authority have you to examine me?—

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What have we here, a Poppet?

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Such a Poppet as you'l be glad to change for the Player you keep—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: You are mistaken, I love the Stage too well to keep any of their women to make 'em proud and insolent, and despise that Calling, to take up a worse.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Then you are none of the Fops I look you for.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I can never rest till I know who has oblig'd me.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Since you are so importunate, I'll give you a Note will discover it, if you'll give me your Honour not to open it will the Masquerade be done.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Upon my Honour I will not.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Now shew your self a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Gad I think I have already—

div.stage: Enter Sir Formal in Scaramoucha's habit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yonder's Sir Formal. You have your Cue, Betty.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam.
You see I am as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: 'Tis she by her Bracelet and Pendants. Madam, had not some disaster intervened, I had sooner kiss'd your hands. But of that, more anon.

div.stage: Enter L. Gimcrack in another disguise.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Now for the rest of my Plot. I shall disappoint these young Sluts, or make mischief enough.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Did not you see Longvil steal out with a woman?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Too well Our Lovers are well match'd.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness I think Bedlam's broke loose and come hither. What a company of Antick Puppies are here? Pox on 'em all. But where is this Figgup? by the Mass I'll not suffer her to go to these Schools of Bawdery; in sadness she'll be too apt a Scholar I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hey Snarl! What, do you come to a Masquerade bare-fac'd?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Yes, that I do, nor am I asham'd of my face, as Rogues and Whores are. Whose Fool are you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, will you please to dance?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: No indeed won't I. I thank God I am not such a Coxcomb yet in sadness.— What do you find in my face to think me such an Owl?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What do you come for then?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Why to find one that should be wiser than to be here, by the Mass.

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: He means me, I shall be undone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Whom do you mean? she that was in the Wood hole?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She that was discover'd in Germin-street.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ounds! I shall be a By-word all over the Town, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: My Uncle here?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Is it she you look for?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What pert-snivelling, squeaking-Baggages are you? here's a squealing with you, with a pox to you.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: To him, Sir Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Sir, let me ask you one civil question.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What civil question would you ask now?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Were not you with a Lady in Germin-street pull'd out by the heels to day?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Ounds! What Rogue art thou? I could find in my heart to beat thee most exorbitantly.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Your Land-lady in Germin-street is a School-mistris, is she not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: O my shame comes upon me! In sadness you are all a company of squealing Coxcombs; wou'd you were all Eunuchs by the Mass, that you might alwayes keep your Treble Voices.

sp.speaker: 1. Bull.
sp.p: What, was this virtuous Gentleman taken with a Whore?

sp.speaker: 2. Bull.
sp.p: Sir, do you very much delight in Birch?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Yes, for mortification-sake. He's a great doer of Pennance.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: A fine old Gentleman, with gray hairs, to be over-taken.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Truly I am sorry a person of your gravity shou'd so expose your discretion.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What damn'd antick Rascal's this?

sp.speaker: Sir. Form.
sp.p: As gad mend me it was uncivil. But, Madam, we will retire, if you please.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: What a Devil, shall I be over-set with Rogues and Fools here—

sp.speaker: 1. Bull.
sp.p: Damn Rogues and Fools.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: So I say, in sadness. The Men are all Rogues and Fools, and the Women all Strumpets, by the Mass, or which are ten times worse, scandalous honest Women. In sadness it is a shame such Bawdy doings should be suffered in a civil Nation; my heart bleeds for't, by the Mass. It was not so in the last Age. Why, what do I talk with a company of Owls for? I come to find one whom I'll never seek again; if she will not appear now—

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: O Buddy, I am here; but I was afraid you'd be an anger'd.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: In sadness I wonder you are not asham'd to come to these vicious scandalous bawdy places. Come away for shame—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I never yet knew one so free of her body, and so nice of her face before. Shall I know no more of you?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Since you will have it so— there's a Note will inform you more: But upon your Honour you must not open it till the Masquerade be over.

sp.speaker: Longv
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: My Dear, I wonder'd I cou'd not see you before.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: O Hazard, have I found thee? this is good luck, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: O infamous damn'd Woman!

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: It makes me break my Spleen almost to think, what an Ass we made of Sir Nicholas to day.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Ay, so it does mine. Ha-ha-ha— A curse on Woman-kind!

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: He, poor Fool, believes ●…s all this while to be as innocent. Now shall you have free liberty to come home to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Shall he so, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sir Sam
sp.p: What's here? one offering violence to a Lady!

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Who, this my Lady Gimcrack?

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: It is my Husband! for Heaven's sake keep him here, till I run home.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Villain! how dare you abuse a Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: It's no matter for that, I shall not discover my self.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: It is Sir Nicholas; now you may lock him up, and be reveng'd of him——

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: No more to be said. Hey! who waits there? Take this Fellow and lock him up, till I talk with him about business.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: ‛ Death! What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have fix'd upon almost every Woman of the Masquerade, and cannot find which is either Clarinda or Miranda.

sp.speaker: 1. Bull.
sp.p: Ounds you lie.—

sp.speaker: 2. Bull.
sp.p: Take that, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: These damn'd Bully Rogues have spoil'd my Intrigue; a pox on 'em all, the Ladies are gone. But I'll find a way to be convey'd into Miranda's Chamber to night yet

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Is not Sir Nicholas within?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: No: but my Lady and the two Ladies are come; my Lady is gone up to my Master's Closet, and the young Ladies are in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: We come to tell Sir Nicholas, we've wholly quell'd the Mutiny, and seen the Offenders committed.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: He will be within presently—

sp.speaker: Long▪
sp.p: I do not see the Ladies here: but this was a very strange adventure at the Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: The Circumstances are so like, had I not seen two several habits, I shou'd believe 'twas the same Woman I have a Note to, and receiv'd the same injunction not to open it.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Let me read your Note, and you shall read mine; the Moon-light will serve for that.
By that means I may discover something.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Agreed. I may perhaps make a discovery.
You see I dare not own my kindness, but when I had something to hide by blushes. I hope you'l use the Conquest like a Gentleman. Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: How! this is to the same effect, subscrib'd by Miranda. There needs no further argument of your treachery, and such as I did not think a Gentleman could be guilty of.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: ‛ Death! Do you accuse me of Treachery, who are your self so great a Traitor? Draw—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Are you so nimble? Have at you—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Hold! hold! hold! for Heaven's sake hold!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Hold! hold! hold! for Heaven's sake hold!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: What means this madness in this place?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: I suppose you ghess at the meaning.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: If not, Miranda can inform you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: This is absolute distraction, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You let Longvil know more of your mind▪ 〈◊〉, in a private Room at the Masquerade to night.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: If she did not, this Lady was kind enough to you there.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What madness is this! I spoke ne'r a word to either of you there.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nor I, Heav'n knows! but we saw each of you steal away with a Lady—

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Do you know that hand, Madam?

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Or you this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: My name subscrib'd!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And here is mine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: This mischief is too evident. This is my Aunts hand.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And this is her Character too. This malice is beyond example, and your baseness, so soon to entertain such thoughts of us.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: That sensless vanity, that makes them think so well of themselves, made 'em think so ill of us.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! what have we done! I beg a thousand pardons for my fault.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Hear but my acknowledgment, on my knees I beg forgiveness for my ill thoughts of so excellent a Lady.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Be gone, unworthy Men, and never see us more.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I'll ne'r forgive the Man that thus dare injure me.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: This damn'd Lady had put her self upon us for two Women. Let's not leave 'em, till we have satisfied them of the occasion of our jealousie.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let's follow at a distance—

div.stage: Enter Clarinda and Miranda, and go into an Arbour.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: They are gone into that Arbour: Let's do an▪ ungenerous thing for once, and listen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Agreed; we then perhaps may hear what their resentments are.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I see we must carry our selves with more reservedness, since Men of Wit and Pleasure are so apt to think ill of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For all this, I love Longvil to that height, I cannot be deserved to him, I can forgive him any thing.
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 too almost to distraction, and could venture any thing but honour for him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 lose 〈◊〉 Life and Love a thousand times before my Virtue. But our cross Love can never meet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The breach was great enough before: but this falshood and malice of my Lady has made it wider. But hold, we are over-heard.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O Heaven! here are Longvil and Bruce—

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: Our case is plain, we have no hopes of succeeding in our intended Loves; or if I had, I wou'd not have the Body without the Mind.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: A man enjoyes as much by a Rape as that way. But I am so pleas'd to find Miranda loves me, that I'd not change for any but Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I have the same opinion of Clarinda's love; and could you be contented, I would willingly change. Gratitude to her will move my heart, more than Miranda's charms with her aversion can.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Since our affections will not thrive in the soil we had plac'd them in, we must trasplant them.

sp.speaker: Longv▪
sp.p: Love, like the Sun-beams, will not warm much, unless reflected back again. It is resolv'd it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Let's follow them now; and while the Metall's hot, 'twill take a Bent the easier.

div.head: SCENA ultima.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Infamous, vile Woman, I'll be reveng'd on all your lewdness.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I have broken open your Closet, and here are all your Letters from your several Whores: And do you think I'll bear your falshood without revenge?

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Be gone out of my doors, I cast you from me; and I have here another Mistriss of this House. Come in.
To you I give possession of all here, Madam. Out of my doors.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p:
Is this one of the Creatures you converse with about Philosophical matters? Fare ye well. I have, thanks to my Friends, a settlement for separate maintenance, and I have
provided for my self too▪ A worthy 〈◊〉: Come in, Sir; he will defend my Person, and my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Who e're shall make such settlements hereafter, may they be plagu'd as I am! Vile Creature—

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Sir, I shall publish your Letters into bargain and send 'em to Gresham-Colledge; then you'll be more despis'd than now you are there—

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: O misfortune! that will be worse than all the miseries can happen to me. Hold, Madam, I have thought on't; and to shew how much I can be a Philosopher, I am content it should be a drawn Battle betwixt us: Do you forgive, and you shall find that I can do so too.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p: O Sir! I bring you the moft unfortunate news that e'r you heard.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: More crosses still!

sp.speaker: Stow.
sp.p: Several Engineers, Glass-makers, and other people you have dealt with for Experiments, have brought Executions, and Extents, and seiz'd on all your Estate in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; you were all this while Botling of Air, and studying Spiders and Glow-worms, stinking Fish, and rotten Wood.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: This last affliction is too great to bear; but I am resolv'd to forgive thee, my Dear, and be a good Husband, and redeem all.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: No, Sir, I thank you; my Settlement is without inbrance, and I'll preserve it without you, which you are the greatest a Woman can have.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly imploy your pardon, for a crime, which Love, which was too strong for my resistance, caused in me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I have marri'd Clarinda; the pretty Creature had an odd fancy to be marri'd in 〈◊〉▪ I hope 〈◊〉 I pardon it; Love is not in our power.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic▪
sp.p: O Heav'n! 〈◊〉 is to 〈◊〉 to all the rest. No, base man, I never will forgive it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, you may if you please, and he too; consider, Sir, Love is not in our power.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: I am amaz'd, I am struck dumb, I ne'r shall speak again!

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: I am sorry for you, Sir Formal; but I have greater sorrows of my own: Yet I have my Uncle Snarl in reserve, I'll try his bounty— Oh here he is!

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Here! Where is this Coxcomb? Nephew— This Vertuoso, I was with a Whore in Germin-street, was I? and your Ladiship reproach'd me too; she is your Aunt in sadness.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: How, Sir! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: Mean! why what shou'd I mean? she is my Wife, I am marri'd to her—

sp.speaker: Fig.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, we are marri'd, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Oh this is worst of all, I have lost all hopes of his Estate, for which I've so long suffer'd all his frowardness.

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: Oh Heav'n! are they so soon come to a right understanding? I am undone. Curse on 'em!

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: O Gentlemen! that foolish Virtuoso, and that wordy Puppy Sir Formal, said, I was taken with a Whore in Germin-street: This is the Lady, and she's my Wife.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to give Sir Formal joy; he is married to Mrs. Betty too.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Upon my sincerity, Madam, it was very uncivilly done, to slur your Maid upon me in your stead: But I must rest contented; no more to be said.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Betty, I wish thee joy; Sir Formal, she's as good a Gentlewoman as you a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: I thought my foolish flashy Orator wou'd be catch'd at last. Ha-ha-ha! what, marry a Chamber-maid!

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: But, Sir, I have not marri'd a Strumpet, as you have.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: How! Is this virtuous Gentleman of the last Age so over-taken?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: Did Gentlemen and men of Honour marry Whores in the last Age?

In sadness they have much ado to avoid it in this; if I have marri'd one, she is my own; and I had better marry
my own than another mans, by the Mass, as 'tis Fifty to one I shou'd, if I had marri'd else-where, in sadness.

sp.speaker: Sir Nil.
sp.p: I have yet a reserve: Nieces, my Land in the Countrey is Extended, and my Goods are seiz'd on: The Money which I have of yours will redeem all, and I will account with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sir, I can do nothing, but by my Guardian's consent; and I have chosen Mr. Longvil for mine.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: And Mr. Bruce has undertaken the protection of my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: ‛ Death! now all my hopes are cut off; I thought to have made a good sum of money of my Nieces. Was this the Philosophy you came for, Gentlemen?
sp.stage: Enter two Porters with Sir Samuel in a Chest.
sp.p: How now? Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Chest of Goods directed to Mrs Miranda, and we were commanded to bring it to her.

sp.speaker: ●…ir.
sp.p: For me! set it down there.

sp.speaker: P●…t.
sp.p: Shall we not carry it into your Chamber, Madam?

sp.speaker: ●…ir.
sp.p: No: there's something for you: be gone.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It stands in the way; Foot-men, set it upon one end.

div.stage: [They offer to turn Sir Samuel with his head down.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Hold, hold; murder, murder!

sp.speaker: Sir Nich.
sp.p: How's this? some Rogue and Thief! pull him out.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Rogue and Thief! I scorn your words.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.p: An Antick Coxcomb; I have seen a Baboon with more common sense.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: I came hither to my Mistriss Miranda, and wou'd marry her about this business.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.p: You must ask my leave, she has chosen me for her Guardian; and I will cut your throat if you attempt to make Love to her any more.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: And do you own what he says, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I must be rul'd by my Guardian.

sp.speaker: Sir Sam.
sp.p: Why then I have been kick'd, beaten, pumpt, and toss'd in a blanket, &c. to no purpose: I am unfortunate in this Intriguo. But no more to be said. Come; 'tis well its no worse yet.

sp.speaker: Sir. Nic.
sp.p: Sure, Sir Formal, you'll not deny me that.

sp.speaker: Sir Form.
sp.p: Truly I opine it not reasonable for one, who has marri'd one with nothing, to be security for another.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: that I shou'd know Men no better! I wou'd I had studi'd Mankind instead of Spiders and Insects. Sure, my Dear, thou wilt not leave me!

sp.speaker: L. Gim.
sp.p: I am resolv'd to part this moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Well, I have something left yet; and here's one loves me, she has told me so a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Flirt
sp.p: Sir, trust not to that; for Women of my profession love Men but as far as their Money goes.

sp.speaker: Sir Nic.
sp.p: Am I deserted by all? Well, now 'tis time to study for use: I will presently find out the Philosophers Stone; I had like to have gotten it last year, but that I wanted May-Dew, being a dry season.

sp.speaker: Longv.
sp.p: I hope, Ladies, since you have put your Estates into our hands, you'll let us dispose of your persons.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: You must have time to leave off your old Love, before you put on new.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Nothing but time can fit it to you.

sp.speaker: Brace.
sp.p: You have given us hope, and we must live on that a while; and sure 'twill not be long that we shall live upon that slender Diet: For,

lg.l: If Love can once a Lady's Out-works win,
It soon will Master all that is within.
NOw you who think y●…are Judges of the Pit,
Who never, but in finding faults, show wit;
Who to your dear dull selves are kind alone,
And ne'r reflect on follies of your own:
Our Poet can from you no mercy find,
Who savage are to all but your own kind.
Nay, on the Stage if some of those appear,
Though ne'r so like your selves, you hate 'em there,
As the whole Herd falls on a wounded Deer.
But of those Ladies he despairs to day,
Who love a dull Romantick whining Play;
Where poor frail Woman's made a Deity,
With sens●…ss amorous Idolatry,
And snivelling Heroes sigh, and pine, and cry.
Though singly they beat Armies, and Hu●…s Kings,
Rant at the Gods, and do impossible things;
Though they can laugh at danger, bloud and wounds;
Yet if the Dame once chides, the milk-sop Hero swoons.
These doughty things, nor Manners have, nor Wit;
We ne'r saw Hero fit to drink with yet.
But hold, I hear some say among the rest,
This Play is not well bred, nor yet well drest;
Such Plays the Womens Poets can write best:
They difser from the Mens, you must allow,
As Womens Taylors Womens Poets too.
But know, good breeding shows its excellence,
Not in small trifling forms, but in good sense.
Yet, Ladies, to Stage-fools some favour show,
Since off the Stage some Fops you can allow.
Few of the Sexes happy Favourites yet
Have been the most remarkable for Wit:
Sure you must like Copies of such as these,
If the Original Coxcombs can so please.
But to the Men of Wit our Poet flies,
And makes his Fops to them a Sacrifice:
You know the pangs, and many labouring throws,
By which your Brains their perfect births disclose.
You can the faults and excellencies find;
Pass by the one, and be to th'other kind.
By you he is resolv'd to stand or fall:
What e'r's his doom he'll not repine at all.
And if this Birth shou'd want its perfect shape,
And cannot by your care its death escape,
Th'abortive Issue came before its day,
And th' Poet has miscarri'd of a Play.
